subsection.heading: 1 Introduction
subsection.p: The notion of ‘pied-piping’ has been an integral part of all versions of the theory of generative grammar that assume transformational movements since it was first introduced by Ross (1986, from his 1967 dissertation). The term itself – attributed by Ross to Robin Lakoff – refers to the phenomenon whereby some particular movement operation T, designated to displace an element A, in fact displaces additional elements together with A; more specifically, pied-piping is involved when an application of T ends up moving some constituent B that properly contains A. Ross's Pied-Piping Convention was originally meant, for instance, to extend the application of the Relative Clause Formation transformation, so that it is able to move more than just the NP immediately dominating the relative pronoun in cases such as shown in (1–2), where (1b, c) and (2a) represent, according to Ross (1986), instances of pied-piping by the relative wh-pronoun.

(1)
a. reports [which] the government prescribes the height of the lettering on . . .
b. reports [the covers of which] the government prescribes the height of the lettering on . . .
c. reports the [lettering on the covers of which] the government prescribes the height of . . .

(2)
a. the boy [whose guardian's employer] we elected president
b. *the boy [whose] we elected guardian's employer president

From its inception until now the existence of pied-piping has uniformly been assumed in the literature, and it has provided a widely used descriptive tool. Yet until recently, the pied-piping phenomenon itself received surprisingly little attention as a research topic in its own right. Thus, while the closely related topics of the proper formulation of, and constraints on, transformational movement operations have always been central to research in syntactic theory, even the most basic questions regarding pied-piping were not raised and addressed in any systematic fashion at least until the early 1990s. A possible reason for this may be the highly theory-dependent nature of pied-piping, namely, the fact that by its very definition, instances of pied-piping can be identified only relative to a particular formulation of the movement operation involved.

Thus, in any theoretical framework in which various movement transformations are formulated in a construction-specific manner, as was the case in the early stages of generative syntax up to the mid 1970s, a general theory of pied-piping could hardly be contemplated. Due to the excessive power of the formalism of transformations, the descriptive effects attributed by Ross to pied-piping could often be easily incorporated into the formulation of the movement transformation itself. There were major discrepancies even involving the best-studied case, namely that of wh-movement, for instance between Ross's (1986) and Emonds's (1976) conception of the phenomenon of pied-piping. Under Ross's notion (see section 1.1), both cases like (1b, c) as well as cases like (2a) were analyzed as instances of the Pied-Piping Convention (given in (8) below); however, under Emonds's alternative proposal, only cases like (1b, c) were such, while those like (2a) were taken to be due to the particular formulation of the wh-movement transformation itself, and were claimed to involve no pied-piping. (See the formulation of wh-movement as moving an NP, AP, or PP with a wh-morpheme at its left periphery, and the analysis of the residue of Ross's pied-piping as a ‘stylistic’ process in Emonds 1976; on the latter idea, see also section 3). Bresnan (1976c) departs from Ross's hypothesis of pied-piping even more radically; her X-Bar theory-based, category-neutral statement of the transformation forming relative clauses eliminates the need for a stipulated pied-piping convention, not only with respect to examples of the type of (2a), but also with respect to examples like (1b, c) since it specifies the constituent that the movement operation applies to as any XP with the categorial feature [−V] (hence any NP or PP) that contains a wh-morpheme.

In the Principles and Parameters (P&P) framework of the 1980s, involving the reduction of the transformational component of the model to the universal Move α schema, and the development of X-Bar theory, as a uniform theory of phrase structure extending to all phrase types, it became possible to ask more general questions regarding the range and properties of pied-piping phenomena; namely, it became in principle feasible to start exploring how general pied-piping behavior is across different constructions, different category types, and across languages, and what its properties and distribution derive from. Yet, possibly due to the highly theory-internal nature of pied-piping, such issues remained essentially uninvestigated during the 1980s as well.

It was only in the 1990s that the general issue of pied-piping started to receive some more comprehensive treatment (e.g., Webelhuth 1992). General questions like the following were raised: What is it that makes pied-piping in individual constructions and with particular phrase types possible while in other cases impossible, and what factors can make it obligatory? What makes it stylistically marked in some particular cases? What is the source of some observed cross-linguistic and cross-categorial discrepancies? What are the structural and possibly non-structural conditions on pied-piping?

In accordance with the modular approach to accounting for syntactic phenomena in terms of interacting principles and parameters of UG, ideally one would like to make the various observed pied-piping options, or lack of those, also fall out of independent properties of UG. Attempts in this direction have been made in the past decade, e.g., by Webelhuth (1992), Moritz and Valois (1994), Chomsky (1995c), Koopman (1997).

The literature on pied-piping up until recently has concentrated mostly on particular cases of A-bar movement, primarily on wh-movements and marginally on some other operator movements, such as negative preposing and quantifier raising. The set of languages investigated, at least with respect to overt pied-piping, has traditionally been limited to mainly English and a few other Germanic languages. Unavoidably, this will be reflected in our discussion as well: it will deal most extensively with wh-constructions, and will use Germanic, and primarily English, data; only some limited amount of comparative material drawn from other languages will be included where relevant.

It needs to be noted here that in the past few years, the above state of affairs started to change, mainly due to two recent developments. One of these, already referred to earlier, was the assumption of movement being feature-driven in the version of the MP presented in Chomsky (1995c), which as a consequence made all cases of movement of elements larger than the “driving” (attracted) features themselves be manifestations of pied-piping. The other factor contributing to the broadening of interest in pied-piping in recent years has been the body of research inspired by Kayne's (1994) Antisymmetry framework, which involves significantly increased reliance on the pied-piping mechanism in the analysis of a variety of languages (see, e.g., Koopman 1996, 1997; Koopman and Szabolcsi 2000; Nkemnji 1995; Pearson 2000b).

Given the sporadic and highly theory and analysis-specific nature of the claims about pied-piping in the literature, the following discussion does not purport to be exhaustive in any sense, and will address only some of the more prominent and influential observations, proposals, and directions for research. The organization of this chapter is as follows.

Section 2 provides a historical perspective on approaches to pied-piping and on the role it played at successive stages in the theory, from Ross (1986) and the Standard Theory (Chomsky 1965) to the current MP framework. Section 3 presents the various descriptive dimensions that pied-piping phenomena manifest, as observed with respect to the best-studied case, namely, instances of wh-movement. It demonstrates the existence of apparent variation according to construction-type based on (restrictive and non-restrictive) relatives, interrogatives, and free relatives, it examines the relevance of the position of the pied-piper within the larger phrase, and it outlines some observed differences relating to category type. Section 4 outlines the major directions and proposals towards a modular, comprehensive, structure-dependent view of pied-piping. Proposals to account for some apparent discrepancies between construction types and for cross-categorial differences will be presented and evaluated. The discussion will include the divergent behavior of PP pied-piping and the controversial issue of clausal pied-piping, as well as some cases of pied-piping under movements other than wh-movement. Section 5 will address the question of LF-pied-piping, that is, the issue of whether or not there is any evidence for the assumption that covert movements may also involve pied-piping. Section 6, finally, outlines the status of pied-piping and what may permit, and in fact force, it within versions of Chomsky's minimalist framework and in other current directions of research, addressing its relation to the PF-interface, to principles of economy and to the phrasal movement vs. head-movement distinction.

subsection.heading: 2 A historical overview: pied-piping and theories of movement
2.1 The Standard Theory and Ross's Pied-Piping Convention
subsection.p: The hypothesis of pied-piping by movement operations and the corresponding Pied-Piping Convention was originally introduced by Ross (1986) as part of his proposal to replace Chomsky's (1964a) A-over-A Principle – see (3) below, accounting for contrasts such as (2a) vs. (2b) – by a set of other constraints on the application of transformations, due to various empirical inadequacies he observed with respect to the former. A classic set of data Ross pointed out as crucial evidence in favor of introducing the option of pied-piping as opposed to maintaining the A-over-A Principle were the set of alternative options shown in (4–5) involving NPs contained within larger NPs moved by the Relative Clause Formation transformation:

li.p: In a structure . . . [A . . . [A . . . ] . . . ] . . . , if a structural description refers to A ambiguously, then that structural description can only analyze the higher, more inclusive, node A.
Reports [which] the government prescribes the height of the lettering on the covers of are invariably boring.

row.entry: Reports [the covers of which] the government prescribes the height of the lettering on almost always put me to sleep.
Reports [the lettering on the covers of which] the government prescribes the height of are a shocking waste of public funds.
Reports [the height of the lettering on the covers of which] the government prescribes should be abolished.

subsection.p: Examples (5a–c) involve movement of larger NPs than just the relative wh-pronoun itself that is designated by the Relative Clause Formation trans-formation to undergo preposing, and at the same time, examples (4) and (5a, b) demonstrate that these data are not attributable to the A-over-A Principle since they in fact violate it. Ross's proposal, beyond his independently argued move to eliminate the A-over-A Principle, was to introduce the Pied-Piping Convention to deal with the facts in (4–5). His actual formulation of the pied-piping option was shaped by some further cases indicating that in contrast to the examples of the type in (5b, c), in certain other configurations the element designated by the transformation to move cannot carry with it, i.e., cannot pied-pipe, a larger phrase containing it. The relevant observations made by Ross, involving coordinate NPs and clauses, are illustrated in (6) and (7) respectively.
(6) *The boy [Bill and who(m)] I watched was vain.

(7)
a. They will give me a hat [which] I know that I won't like.
b. *They will give me a hat [that I won't like which] I know.
Accordingly, Ross states the Pied-Piping Convention, intended as a universal convention for the application of transformations, as follows:

li.p: Any transformation which is stated in such a way as to effect the reordering of some specified node NP, where this node is preceded and followed by variables in the structural index of the rule, may apply to this NP or to any non-coordinate NP which dominates it, as long as there are no occurrences of any coordinate node, nor of the node S, on the branch connecting the higher node and the specified node.

subsection.p: It needs to be noted here that the Pied-Piping Convention was crucially stated as taking along a larger phrase only optionally. This was appropriate for cases such as (4–5). However, in a well-defined set of instances, pied-piping seemed to apply obligatorily, as shown by (9a, b):

(9)
a. *the boy [whose] we elected guardian's employer president
b. *the boy [whose guardian's] we elected employer president
c. the boy [whose guardian's employer] we elected president

It is this phenomenon – being essentially a residual A-over-A effect – for which Ross proposed the Left Branch Condition (10); this condition renders the application of pied-piping in such cases in effect obligatory.

li.p: The Left Branch Condition (LBC)
No NP which is the leftmost constituent of a larger NP can be reordered out of this NP by a transformational rule.

subsection.p: Ross's statement of the Pied-Piping Convention, as well as the LBC, refer only to the category NP. But at the time, his category NP crucially included also PPs; PPs were considered by Ross as NPs immediately dominating P and NP, so movements carrying along Ps were analyzed as cases of pied-piping under this formulation as well. Furthermore, APs and AdvPs too were taken by Ross to be derived from or dominated by NPs, hence their obligatory pied-piping effects were also assumed to be covered by this formulation of the convention and of the LBC. The marked increase of category types in the course of the evolution of the theory in subsequent decades had an obvious impact on the issue of identifying the set of categories involved in pied-piping.

Unlike the highly construction-specific transformations themselves characteristic of the Standard Theory of the 1960s assumed also by Ross, the Pied-Piping Convention clearly was conceived as applying in a general way, to all transformational movements, and irrespective of construction type. In addition to examples involving the Relative Clause Formation transformation, Ross (1986) demonstrated the pied-piping phenomenon, and the effects of conditions on its application, with respect to transformations such as the wh-movement rule forming interrogatives (his Question Rule), Topicalization and Heavy NP Shift (the latter two cases are exemplified in (11) and (12), respectively).

(11)
a. The boy's guardian's employer we elected president.
b. *The boy's guardian's we elected employer president.

(12)
a. We elected president the boy's guardian's employer.
b. *We elected employer president the boy's guardian's.

As for the issue of the universal status of the convention and cases of apparent cross-linguistic variation with respect to pied-piping phenomena, Ross noted problems at least in two major areas. One such case involved the LBC, which turned out not to apply in some languages, as for instance Russian and Latin; hence Ross proposed that it is a condition specified in particular grammars. The other area that posed important problems for the Pied-Piping Convention was the variation among languages with respect to PPs: stranding vs. pied-piping of Ps seemed not to be a free choice in particular languages as would be expected based on the convention. The stranding of Ps was known to be prohibited in a variety of languages (e.g., German, French, Italian, Russian), i.e., pied-piping of P was obligatory. On the other hand, in languages like Danish and English, pied-piping of Ps was claimed to be prohibited in some specific environments, as exemplified below for English by (13a, b) (=Ross's (4.211b, c)).

(13)
a. ?*Did you notice of which difficulties she made light?
b. *Of whom are you trying to get hold?

Ross incorporated these cases of variation as separate stipulated conditions on pied-piping that appear in individual grammars, and left the original formulation of the convention in UG. Most of the empirical issues involved remain essentially unresolved until today.

subsection.heading: 2.2 Pied-piping in the GB model: X-Bar Theory and Move α
subsection.p: The major shift in the theory that took place in the 1980s GB era, replacing the Standard Theory's assumption of language-particular grammars with the Principles-and-Parameters theory, naturally resulted in a change in the view of the pied-piping mechanism as well. One factor that had an important impact on the kinds of questions that could be raised with respect to pied-piping was the development of a full-fledged X-Bar theory of phrase structure. A relevant aspect of this development was the postulation of new phrasal categories with a uniform X-Bar structure for categories that previously either had been neglected – as for instance the category PP, as distinct from NP, and the subsequently introduced DP, projected by D(et) (see, e.g., Brame 1982; Szabolcsi 1983; Abney 1987) – or had been assigned an exocentric structure, radically different from the rest of the phrasal categories, such as the clausal categories S and S′, which have become known since Chomsky (1986a) as IP, headed by I, and CP, headed by C. This in turn resulted in an increased number of category types which exhibited a uniform, precisely articulated internal hierarchical structure, with structurally defined relations such as Spec–Head and Head–Complement, and for which cross-categorial generalizations were expected to hold in principle, and had in fact been observed with respect to various empirical domains. Given this, the issue of whether the pied-piping phenomenon is category-neutral or not and if not, why not, became an obvious subject for empirical inquiry.

This direction leading towards the need for a more general, non-stipulative theory of pied-piping was further reinforced by the elimination of individual transformations in favor of the universal maximally general ‘Move α’ schema for transformational movement, permitting in principle free movement of any category to any position. With construction-particular statements of transformations gone, the task of accounting for observed properties of and limitations on actual movement options got assigned to universal constraints and principles, with a limited number and kinds of open parameters, within UG. UG acquired a rich modular structure consisting of a variety of subsystems of principles (e.g., theta theory, Case theory, binding theory, locality conditions); it was the interaction of these that was supposed to derive the actual clusters of empirical phenomena recognized descriptively as ‘constructions’, which had earlier been accounted for by stipulating various individual construction-specific transformations. Since under Move α any size constituents could undergo movement in any construction, unless it resulted in violation of a UG principle or condition, the challenge with respect to pied-piping in this framework became quite different from the situation in Ross's time. For Ross, what needed explanation in the first place, and what led him to introduce the Pied-Piping Convention, was the existence of cases when a ‘larger-than-expected’ constituent moved; in contrast, in the GB era, what was in need of an account was the large set of cases where pied-piping seemed to be impossible, for apparently no known reason. In other words, movements in effect became completely unlimited under the Move α schema, making the Pied-Piping Convention as such entirely redundant, and just like other instances of overgeneration by movements, cases as, e.g., those in (14–16), involving apparently illegitimate pied-piping effects, needed to be excluded in new, non-stipulative ways.
(14) *We wondered [the rumors about whom] shocked Mary.
(15) *[Some how old boys] have you met?
(16) *[Read what] has John?

The first systematic investigation into the nature and limitations of what pretheoretically continued to be referred to as pied-piping phenomena in the GB framework was presented by Webelhuth (1992: ch. 4). Webelhuth's study explored wh-movements in the Germanic languages, and arrived at a set of important structure-dependent descriptive generalizations about what positions in terms of X-Bar theory and in what types of phrases can serve as pied-pipers. His actual account of the generalizations he uncovered was based on a modular view of UG, and involved the interaction of independently motivated principles, such as the theta criterion, the definition of syntactic operator, the Bijection Principle, the definition of the modification relation, and others. (For a discussion of Webelhuth's analysis, see section 4.)

Other work on pied-piping during the GB period concentrated on more limited issues, such as the existence of clausal pied-piping and the severe restrictions on it in languages like English and German, studied, e.g., in Nanni and Stillings (1978), Ishihara (1984), and Van Riemsdijk (1985). (On CP pied-piping see also section 4.5 below.) Another specific aspect of pied-piping addressed in the 1980s was the issue of LF-pied-piping, debated primarily (a) in relation to apparent violations of Subjacency in cases of (alleged) covert wh-movement of in situ wh-phrases by Choe (1987), Nishigauchi (1990), Pesetsky (1987a), Fiengo et al. (1988), and (b) in relation to May's (1985) QR-based account of antecedent-contained deletion (ACD). (See also chapter 77 and a general overview of LF-pied-piping in section 5.) Some more general remarks about S-structure pied-piping phenomena involving wh-movement were presented by Kayne (1984a: ch. 8) with reference to his notion of g-projection set.

subsection.heading: 2.3 A Minimalist perspective: feature movement and the status of pied-piping
subsection.p: One major innovation that characterized the emerging Minimalist research program of the 1990s involved a change in the conception of movement operations. The minimalist framework (Chomsky 1995c) incorporated in a strict and systematic way the earlier idea of movement having a last-resort character. This was made precise by claiming that movement in the syntactic derivation, i.e., in the computational system (CS), must always be ‘driven’, and specifically, it is possible only for the satisfaction of abstract morphological requirements, namely, for the checking of uninterpretable formal features (such as Case, phi-features, etc.) occurring on lexical items. The assumption that all movements are feature-driven led directly to the proposal that the movement operation Move/Attract applies only to the formal features themselves. In other words, movement in the MP framework of the 1990s was conceived of as feature movement, rather than movement of full categories (but see Chomsky 2000 for a revision of the idea of feature movement). If so, as argued by Chomsky (1995c), any case in which more than just the formal features of items move is an instance of the application of pied-piping. Thus any displacement of overt material is construed in this framework as a case of pied-piping. (On what forces such pied-piping, related issues of economy and predictions regarding LF-pied-piping, see Chomsky 1995c and section 6 below.) This extended notion of pied-piping is referred to in the MP literature as generalized pied-piping.

Observe here the contrast arising between the status of pied-piping in GB theory and pied-piping in the above version of the MP framework. While anything could in principle move under ‘Move α’, so the crucial question in the GB frameweork was how to exclude – usually by various well-formedness and interpretive conditions – unwanted instances of pied-piping, the issue is exactly the reverse under Chomsky's (1995c) MP. Other things being equal, nothing can move, in accordance with the notion of derivational economy, apart from formal features, and those move only when needed for feature checking. Hence the actual occurrence of any movement of elements ‘larger’ than such features not only constitutes pied-piping in this version of the MP, but more importantly, pied-piping itself needs to be accounted for in terms of what forces it under the MP notion of economy.

Chomsky (1995c) suggests the strong hypothesis that all pied-piping is forced by needs of the PF-interface. Bare feature movement results in scattered, isolated features, which as such are uninterpretable for the PF component, i.e., they cannot be pronounced. So pied-piping of (at least) the full lexical item bearing the relevant feature would be forced to take place in order to repair this, and thus to prevent the derivation from crashing at PF. The empirical challenge such a proposal faces is of course to find motivated PF-based reasons for the observed pied-piping of various larger than minimal pronounceable constituents (e.g., various phrasal categories). This unified PF-interface hypothesis of (generalized) pied-piping opens up some intriguing questions for future research, such as the problems raised by the existence of both head movement and phrasal movement in the theory, when both are assumed to be feature-driven, or for instance the question of the proper analysis of apparent cases of large-scale pied-piping and of the coexistence of alternative pied-piping options with respect to the same element (see also section 6).

subsection.heading: 3 Descriptive dimensions of pied-piping: wh-movement
subsection.p: The main body of phenomena considered as uncontroversial cases of pied-piping in the literature of the past three decades manifests variation along a number of different dimensions. Using the best-studied case, namely, pied-piping under wh-movement, the following subsections will sort out and organize the observed pied-piping phenomena along these distinct but interrelated dimensions. Each subsection will discuss one such dimension, keeping the rest of the factors of variation constant as much as possible. This outline of the relevant descriptive dimensions will be providing the empirical foundation and frame of reference for the discussion of proposed accounts in section 4.

subsection.heading: 3.1 Construction-specific variation
subsection.p: Contrary to what might be expected (other things being equal) under the conception of pied-piping as a unified property of movements, it turns out that at least prima facie, pied-piping applies differently to different construction types. Thus, three core cases of wh-movement construction of English, each involving an overt wh-morpheme, exhibit three distinct patterns of possible pied-piping. One such unexpected contrast holds between pied-piping options in relative clauses – of the type that led Ross to propose the Pied-Piping Convention in the first place – and pied-piping options in wh-questions. As will be demonstrated in section 3.1.1, a specific set of pied-piping cases exist in English with respect to relative clauses formed by wh-movement but not with respect to corresponding interrogatives being formed by wh-movement. In addition to this apparent relative–interrogative wh-movement contrast, a third distinct pattern of pied-piping options is attested in the case of wh-movement forming free relatives. As will be shown in section 3.1.2, pied-piping effects in free relatives are even more limited than they are in the case of wh-interrogatives. In a set of well-defined subcases, pied-piping by the wh-word seems impossible in free relatives while the same phrase can be pied-piped both in (restrictive and non-restrictive) headed relatives and in wh-questions.

subsection.heading: 3.1.1 Restrictive and non-restrictive relative clauses vs. wh-questions
subsection.p: Pied-piping under wh-movement has been observed to be most permissive in the case of relative clauses, and especially in non-restrictive relatives (on a contrast observed between pied-piping in restrictive and non-restrictive relatives, see the discussion of (21a, b) and (21c) below, as well as section 4.3.1). Consider first the kind of relative clause data (discussed also by Webelhuth 1992) that was used by Ross as the initial motivation for the Pied-Piping Convention.

(17)
a. Reports [the height of the lettering on the covers of which] the government prescribes should be abolished.
b. He is a linguist [articles by whom] the editors always reject.
c. This is the kind of woman [proud of whom] I could never be.

Crucially, it turns out that the corresponding wh-questions are unacceptable. (The unacceptability of such pied-piping is even sharper in embedded interrogatives than in matrix ones, possibly due to interference from echo questions in the latter cases, as noted in Kayne 1994.)

(18)
a. *[The height of the lettering on the covers of which reports] did the government prescribe?
b. *We don't know [articles by whom] the editors have rejected.
c. *I asked Bill [proud of whom] he has always been.

Descriptively speaking, what seems to characterize the wh-phrases that manifest contrasting pied-piping options in relatives vs. in wh-questions in English is that the wh-word itself in these types of phrases is located to the right of the head of the phrase (this will be made more precise in section 3.2). The cross-linguistic status of the above type of data suggests that it is the possibility of such (apparent) pied-piping in English relatives, rather than its unavailability in English wh-questions, that is special in some way, i.e., that is the unexpected aspect of the contrast. The reason is that relative clauses in the other Germanic languages uniformly fail to permit such instances of pied-piping, as shown for instance by Webelhuth's (1992: 129) examples for German, Dutch (see (19–20)), as well as for Swedish, Danish, and Norwegian.

(19)
*der Präsident, [ein Bild von dem] an der Wand hing German
the president a picture of whom at the wall hung

(20)
*de president, [een foto van wie] aan de muur hing Dutch
the president a picture of whom at the wall hung

Observe furthermore that such cases of pied-piping in English relatives as in (17) contrast not only with corresponding English wh-interrogatives, and not only are they ungrammatical in the other Germanic languages, but they also vary in acceptability among themselves. A systematic aspect of the latter kind of variation is pointed out by Emonds (1985: 304, n. 20).

Emonds claims that the marginal status and variability of judgments hold for pied-piping of this type specifically within restrictive relatives, indicating that such cases when acceptable, are only ‘derivatively’ generated, on the model of non-restrictive relatives. He bases this claim on restrictive relatives such as in (21a, b), where interference from non-restrictive relatives is reduced by the choice of the heads of these relatives (which would be inappropriate as heads of non-restrictive relatives), and on their contrast with the non-restrictive relative (21c). (Emonds's judgments below are not uniformly shared by speakers.)

(21)
a. ?We should visit only the city [a favorable report on which] Jack received.
b. *Most students are interested in any professor [a security file on whom] the government won't release.
c. Most students are interested in Prof. Rotestern, [the security file on whom] the government won't release.
He concludes that pied-piping by a post-head wh-word is a legitimate, though stylistically literary, option only for non-restrictive relatives.
In sum, pied-piping (by a wh-word) in English has been shown to be more limited in questions than in relatives, or at least than in non-restrictive relatives.

subsection.heading: 3.1.2 Free relatives
subsection.p: Consider next the following contrast between wh-questions and headed relatives on the one hand and free relatives on the other, involving a type of pied-piping not discussed in section 3.1.1, namely, pied-piping when the wh-word occurs to the left of the head of the relevant phrase:

row.entry: I wonder [whose mother's picture] is hanging on the wall.
the person [whose mother's picture] is hanging on the wall
*[Whose mother's picture] is hanging on the wall should be fired.

subsection.p: The impossibility of pied-piping within free relatives demonstrated in (24b, c) above, and their striking contrast with the perfectly grammatical corresponding wh-questions and overtly headed relatives (as in (22b, c) and (23b, c)) was first pointed out and analyzed in Grosu (1989). As demonstrated by Grosu, this severe limitation on free relatives with respect to pied-piping effects is not specific to English, but holds for the full range of languages (e.g., also in German, Romanian, Finnish, Latin, Classical Greek), and is independent of where the particular free relatives fall in terms of the matching parameter (see also Grosu 1994 and chapter 27). The proposed account, based on the need of local identification for the pro head of the free relative, will be discussed in section 4.3.2.

subsection.heading: 3.2 The phrase-internal position of the pied-piper
subsection.p: The phenomena introduced in section 3.1.1 already suggested that the position of the potential pied-piper within a phrase is a relevant factor in determining whether that particular phrase will or will not undergo pied-piping. Specifically, we have seen that with the exception of some relative clauses in a literary register of English, pied-piping in the Germanic languages under wh-movement is possible only if the wh-word occurs to the left of the head of the phrase (see, e.g., (18), (19), and (20)). This observation needs to be made more precise by exploring the exact nature of the apparent constraint on the position of the pied-piper within the relevant phrase. Consider first the contrast shown in (25) and (26) regarding pied-piping options for DPs in English:

(25)
a. I wonder [whose articles] they read.
b. I wonder [which airport] is the busiest.

(26)
a. *I wonder [articles by whom/which linguists] they read.
b. *I wonder [the airport where/in which city] is the busiest.

Descriptively speaking, the relevant generalization in this set of examples is that a DP can get pied-piped under wh-movement only when the wh-word is either to the left of the head, more precisely, as suggested by (29–30) below, occupying its Spec position (as in (25a)) or is the head D itself (as in (25b)). When it follows the head of the phrase, specifically, when it is a complement of the lexical head or a modifier (adjunct), as in (26a, b), then it cannot induce pied-piping of the phrase. A similar pattern is observed also in the case of pied-piping of APs.
(27) I wonder [how proud of his achievements] your brother is.
(28) *I wonder [very proud of what/whose achievements] your brother is.

At this point one may still assume that the observed generalization about the pied-piper's phrase-internal position involves linear order with respect to the head, rather than notions of hierarchical structure and corresponding grammatical relations within the phrase. But consider the following relevant data from English and German DPs, as well as APs in German, discussed in Webelhuth (1992):

(29)
a. *[The/Some how old books] has John lost?
b. *[Die wie
alten Bücher] hat Hans verloren?
the how old books has Hans lost

(30)
*[Auf wen
sehr stolz] ist Hans?
of whom very proud is Hans

In (29a, b) the wh-word is to the left of the lexical head of the phrase, yet it cannot induce pied-piping. But this is precisely what one would expect if the correct generalization was based on hierarchical position in terms of X-Bar theory: unlike in (25) and (27), here the wh-word is not in the Spec position of the pied-piped phrase, but is in an adjunct of the noun phrase, namely, in an attributive-adjective phrase. The example in (30) provides even stronger evidence against a linear precedence-based generalization for what can be a pied-piper in a phrase. It shows that even though in German PP-complements of adjectives are possible both to the right and to the left of the head A (see Webelhuth 1992: 122), pied-piping of the AP by a pre-head wh-complement is still impossible, just like it is with post-head ones. Again, this suggests that it is being a complement rather than a Spec of the AP that is the crucial factor blocking pied-piping by the wh-word here, and not linear position.

Finally, one might perhaps try to claim at this point that all the above cases where the wh-word could not act as a pied-piper, (26), (28), (29), and (30) are due to a requirement that the pied-piper needs to be adjacent to the left periphery of the phrase, i.e., needs to be in absolute initial position. But notice that this amended linear alternative turns out to be inadequate as well, in light of the following evidence from pied-piping data involving Hungarian DPs (on a detailed analysis of the latter see Szabolcsi 1983 and subsequent work). The Hungarian facts indicate that in fact the pied-piper need not be initial in the pied-piped phrase.

(31)
a. [János melyik
fiát] szereted legjobban? Hungarian
John which son-3Sg Poss-Acc like-2Sg best
‘Which son of John's do you like most?’
b. [Az anyád hány
barátnőjének] telefonáltál?
the mother-2Sg Poss how many woman-friend-3Sg Poss-Dat phoned-2Sg
‘How many of your mother's friends did you call?’

The type of facts presented in this subsection leads to the conclusion that the position of the (potential) pied-piper in the relevant phrase is a major factor in determining whether pied-piping will or will not be possible. Furthermore, the descriptive generalization emerging from the data so far is that specifiers and heads of phrases are able to induce pied-piping, whereas complements and adjuncts are not pied-pipers. (For further elaboration of this generalization and for proposed accounts, see Webelhuth 1992: ch. 4 and sections 3.3 and 4.)

subsection.heading: 3.3 Category type of the pied-piped phrase
subsection.p: An additional dimension of variation with respect to pied-piping phenomena involves the category type of phrases undergoing pied-piping. Even if we limit ourselves to the core set of category types that were assumed already during the GB period, we find that not all phrasal categories undergo the same range of pied-piping phenomena; rather there seem to exist some category-specific differences in pied-piping under wh-movement.

The case of DPs, APs, and AdvPs is the most straightforward. They can get pied-piped under wh-movement, as expected based on what we saw in sections 3.1 and 3.2. Specifically, the general case of pied-piping attested both in wh-questions and in relatives shown in section 3.1 (where the pied-piping wh-word is a specifier or a head) occurs consistently with all three of these categories. Furthermore, in languages like English, which exhibit Left Branch Condition effects, they get pied-piped obligatorily.

li.p: She wondered [whose closest friends] you had invited to the party.
I wonder [how proud of his achievements] is your brother?
I wonder [how well] she remembers her early childhood.

subsection.p: The cases of PPs and of clausal projections with respect to pied-piping options are far more complex, and they exhibit some patterns that are unexpected under the generalizations reached in section 3.2 above.

Regarding PPs, the major phenomenon to observe involves the existence of standard (not stylistically restricted) pied-piping of PP by a wh-word or phrase in its complement position, instantiated in wh-questions as well as in the various types of relatives; this is in contrast with the case of the other phrase types discussed, where complements were not pied-pipers. The pied-piping of Ps involves significant language particular variation: some languages, such as those permitting preposition stranding (see chapter 50), e.g., the Scandinavian languages and (colloquial versions of) English, exhibit pied-piping by the complement of P only optionally, and in certain cases not at all, whereas in a wide variety of other languages, including German, French, Spanish, and Russian, complements of P pied-pipe obligatorily under wh-movement. Pied-piping of PP by a wh-complement is illustrated below from German and Dutch.

Beyond the surprising behavior of complements of P, pied-piping by wh-elements in Spec is possible (though contrary to Ross's Left Branch Condition, is not obligatory), and pied-piping by modifiers is impossible, as expected based on the discussion in section 3.2:

row.entry: [How many feet behind the house] should I put the table?
Cf. [How many] feet should I put the table behind the house?
*[Where into the kitchen] did John go?

subsection.p: What is left to examine now is the behavior of the extended projections of V (in the sense of Grimshaw 1991), i.e., VP and the clausal functional projections postulated above VP. With respect to these clausal projections, we will limit our discussion here to the highest canonical clausal projection, namely to CP. (On proposals involving pied-piping of IP, in particular to Spec of CP, see, for instance, Sportiche's 1995 argument from French intonational yes–no questions, and Koopman's 1996; 1997 IP-pied-piping account of subject-wh extraction in English.)

Let us consider first the question of whether VPs undergo pied-piping under wh-movement. Notice that under the VP-internal subject hypothesis, the external argument of V originates in the Spec of VP and it undergoes A-movement to Spec of IP (at least in languages like English). This means that the Spec of VP is filled by a trace, hence it cannot be tested for whether a wh-element in it could or could not pied-pipe the VP under wh-movement. As for other positions in the VP, consider the set of data given below in (38) and (39) (Webelhuth 1992: 123–124); what it demonstrates is that neither a wh-complement nor a wh-adjunct may induce pied-piping of a VP.

(38)
a. *[Read what] has John?
b. *[Was
gelesen] hat Hans?
what read has Hans

(39)
a. *[How closed the door] has John?
b. *[Wie
die Tür geschlossen] hat Hans?
how the door closed has Hans

The issue of pied-piping of clauses under wh-movement presents a less uniform situation; in the literature there are some well-known, though controversial, claims regarding particular languages, e.g. Basque and German, permitting some varieties of clausal (CP) pied-piping. In this section we will present only the basic cases, focusing on English, and return to discuss some further more controversial, and language-specific cases in the overview of CP-pied-piping in section 4.5.

As noted in Webelhuth (1992: 126) based on examples from English (non-echo) wh-questions with a finite CP complement, such as (40) below, pied-piping of CP by a wh-element in its IP complement is impossible, irrespective of whether the wh-phrase occupies Spec, complement or adjunct position in the IP.

(40)
a. *[That who met John] did Mary know?
b. *[That John met who(m)] did Mary know?
c. *[That John left when] did Mary know?

Similarly, pied-piping of infinitival CPs by a wh-element in IP is also impossible, as shown below by the (non-echo) question in (41). The same is true for standard (not stylistically marked) relative clauses as well. (On the case of non-standard extensive pied-piping in the stylistically marked, literary versions of relatives in English introduced in section 3.1.1 above, which includes also certain instances of clausal pied-piping, see section 4.3.1.)
(41) *[To meet who(m)] would Mary be very happy?
Finally, turning to the important issue of whether a wh-element occupying the Spec position in CP may or may not act as a pied-piper for the whole CP, consider the following:

row.entry: *[Which boys to invite] did John suggest?

subsection.p: This type of data seem to indicate clearly that no CP pied-piping is possible under wh-movement, at least in English, and according to Webelhuth's (1992) claim, in the other Germanic languages either (on a controversial case of clausal pied-piping in German by a relative pronoun, see section 4.5). However, it is worth noting here that English still exhibits a construction which at least prima facie suggests that this statement may turn out to be too strong. Thus, although subject to a number of hitherto unexplored limitations, the sentence-type exemplified in (43) below might appear to instantiate CP-pied-piping by a wh-specifier in English (this case was originally pointed out by Anna Szabolcsi (p.c.), and was referred to in relation to the analysis of so-called partial wh-movement constructions in Horvath (1998, n. 10) and Kayne (2000: ch. 13, n. 107).

(43)
a. [Where did he go], do you think?
b. [Who left last night], do you think?

Whether cases like (43a, b) indeed instantiate CP-pied-piping is however far from unequivocal. The presence of main clause properties in the allegedly pied-piped embedded CP, such as the requirement of being tensed (cf. (42a) and (43)), and most prominently the obligatory application of subject-auxiliary inversion (as in (43a)), suggests an alternative analysis involving no clausal pied-piping (on ‘root phenomena’ in embedded vs. main clause contexts, see chapter 23). Under the latter alternative, the bracketed clause in (43a, b) is the main clause, and the rest of the sentence (do you think) would be taken to be a parenthetical. However, until an in-depth systematic investigation of the topic is undertaken, no firm conclusion can be reached regarding the proper analysis of this curious construction type.

subsection.heading: 4 Issues and proposed analyses
subsection.p: In this section we will approach the various observations regarding pied-piping effects under wh-movement reviewed in section 3 in a systematic theory-bound manner. The section will present and discuss proposals aimed at developing a comprehensive account that could integrate the descriptive generalizations reached with respect to wh-movements, together with other known pied-piping phenomena, into a general theory of pied-piping, possibly involving the interaction of several independent modules of UG. Within the framework of the P&P conception of UG, and in particular, assuming versions of this theory that have emerged since the early 1990s, it is helpful to organize the discussion of the observed pied-piping effects and the proposed accounts around the following two general questions:

li.p: Given that by definition, any movement potentially involving pied-piping is (under current assumptions) driven by the need for some element smaller than the pied-piped phrase (e.g., a lexical item, or a formal feature) to be placed in a new position, what are the conditions that enable the pied-piping operation to take place, i.e., what makes movement of the larger constituent containing the element actually driving the movement operation possible in the first place?

How does the particular structure arising from the application or non-application of a pied-piping operation satisfy or violate assumed general well-formedness conditions on the output of syntactic computations (such as the requirements on operator-variable chains, the Bijection Principle, the theta criterion, or the identification of phonologically null elements)?

subsection.p: The primary focus of our discussion below will be question (i), and aspects of question (ii) will be brought in only to the extent that they directly bear on the particular empirical phenomena under discussion. Otherwise, issues such as for instance what mechanisms are needed for assigning correct interpretations at the LF-interface (with respect to anaphor binding, scope, etc.) to elements within pied-piped structures, and specifically the issue of the need for and the nature of a reconstruction mechanism, will not be addressed (on the latter, see chapter 54).

Based on the facts presented in section 2, it is clear that the answer to question (i) cannot be that pied-piping is free, i.e., that any moving element can pied-pipe any phrase dominating it. But at the outset, it also needs to be noted that the patterns of occurrence of pied-piping do not seem to be adequately accounted for based on the initially appealing idea that it is a default mechanism, namely, that pied-piping applies if and only if extraction of the smaller element driving the movement is prohibited. This type of hypothesis turns out to run into problems when we consider, for instance, cases where either a wh-element in Spec position of a phrase or the whole phrase itself may undergo the same movement operation, without resulting in any stylistic markedness; see, e.g., the case of English PPs with a wh-specifier as [[how many feet] behind the house] in example (36) above, or pied-piping options of DPs by wh-specifiers in languages such as Russian, where the Left Branch Condition seems not to apply, and extraction of the specifier is permitted. Furthermore, the above idea of ‘free pied-piping as default’ is also shown inadequate by cases where, although the wh-elements occur within extraction islands such as, e.g., complex-NPs, coordinate structures, adjuncts, etc., yet the dominating large phrase cannot get pied-piped, in spite of the unavailability of wh-extraction (see e.g. (44b)):

row.entry: *They knew what he felt guilty [after saying t].
*They knew [after saying what] he felt guilty.

subsection.p: Thus, there clearly seem to be some substantive structure-sensitive prerequisites for pied-piping to take place.

subsection.heading: 4.1 What can pied-pipe a phrase?
subsection.p: A logical starting point for the exploration of the essence of pied-piping, and one that also reflects the main direction of current research on the subject (such as in Webelhuth 1992: ch. 4; Koopman 1996, 1997) is provided by the initial descriptive generalization (see (45)) reached in section 3.2 regarding the structural position of pied-pipers vs. non-pied-pipers within their phrase (manifested most transparently in the case of DPs and APs, as, e.g., (25a, b), (27) vs. (26a, b), (28–30)):

li.p: Given a phrase XP,

row.entry: the head X and the specifier YP are pied-pipers for XP;
complements of X and modifiers (adjuncts) are not pied-pipers for XP.

subsection.p: Some of the empirical phenomena reviewed in section 3 represent apparently major deviations from this primary generalization. Such are, obviously, the stylistically marked heavy pied-piping cases attested in relative clauses in English (shown in section 3.1.1), more importantly, the widely attested case of PP pied-piping by a complement of P, and also the case of CPs (shown in section 3.3), as well as the case of DPs in free relatives (in section 3.1.2), both of which appear not to get pied-piped even by their specifier. Each of these apparent deviations from the generalization in (45) will be reexamined and dealt with in sections 4.3, 4.4, and 4.5.

Further exploration of the statement in (45), reveals that it is not fully adequate in its present form even for the apparently straightforward DP and AP cases that it was primarily motivated by. Beyond examples such as (25a, b) and (27) representing cases of legitimate pied-piping, consider data of the following type, manifesting additional pied-piping options; such data argue for making the statement of (45) somewhat more general.
(46) They wondered [whose daughter's teacher] the school had fired.

In the above cases the pied-piped phrase, namely a DP, has a wh-word in it (whose), however this itself is neither the head nor the specifier of the moved phrase. In (46), the pied-piper whose is the specifier of the specifier of the moved DP. What this suggests is that being a pied-piper for a phrase via the specifier relation, as stated in (45), is a transitive relation, so that also a Spec of a Spec (of a Spec) of a phrase can act as a pied-piper for the phrase. In the following section we will elaborate the core pied-piping generalizations presented above, and discuss proposals for the underlying mechanism from which they may derive.

subsection.heading: 4.2 The core cases: projection and the Spec–Head relation
subsection.p: Conceptually, the generalizations summarized in (45) and amended above based on (46) seem reasonable, given what is known about the various structural positions within phrase structure. Heads project their features, thus giving rise to higher (phrasal) categories, and, consequently, phrases by definition exhibit features of their heads. Thus any feature on a head that may be driving a movement operation is available on the phrase projected from that head, hence the particular movement operation may in principle move the phrase itself, resulting in ‘pied-piping’ of a phrase by (features of) its head. The only other feature-sharing (agreement) relationship permitted in restrictive theories of phrase structure since Chomsky's Barriers (1986a) is between the specifier and the head of the phrase. This Spec–Head agreement relation offers an obvious account for pied-piping of a phrase by its Spec, provided the additional assumption that this agreement relation is dynamic in the sense that features of a specifier that the head does not possess may be inherited by this head under the Spec–Head agreement relation. (For some empirical consequences of this latter assumption, see the discussion of operator features and CP-pied-piping by wh under Webelhuth's (1992) analysis in section 4.5, as well as Grosu's (1994) ‘anti-pied-piping’ effects presented in 4.3.2.)

Koopman (1997) explicitly formulates the hypothesis that the pied-piped category inherits the feature relevant for the checking relation driving the movement through projection from the head. Furthermore, according to Koopman's hypothesis, as well as to Koopman and Szabolcsi (2000), a head can acquire such a feature in two ways (or through a combination of these two ways): the feature may originate in Spec position, and a head may inherit it through (a series of) Spec–Head agreement relations, assumed to involve a ‘dynamic’ type of agreement (as illustrated in (47)); alternatively, the head may inherit a feature through head movement, i.e., through a lower head bearing the feature being raised to it (this latter way will be presented in section 4.4, in the context of PP-pied-piping by a complement of P).

li.p: XP inherits a feature from its *specifier (where ‘*specifier’ is the transitive closure of the specifier relation).

E.g.:
(Koopman 1997 and Koopman and Szabolcsi 2000: 41)

subsection.p: In this case, ZP, being the specifier of YP, agrees with the head Y; Y's features are the features of its maximal projection YP. YP itself, being the specifier of XP, agrees with the head X, and features of X are features of its maximal projection XP. Hence XP is able to get pied-piped under movement applying to phrases bearing the feature z.

This type of account, based on mechanisms of feature inheritance and projection, is relevant for all movement operations that are driven by the presence of some syntactically active (formal) feature; its consequences extend both to A-bar movement (operator–variable) constructions, like the case of wh-movement under discussion, as well as to cases of A-movement, where there is no operator, and the features involved are inflectional ones, such as, e.g., Case and phi-features. What is important to note here though is that the above proposal for deriving the observed core pied-piping generalizations makes sense only if the movements involved are feature driven. If on the other hand, the overt movement of phrases were not driven by needs of feature checking, but rather for instance by an EPP property of some functional heads requiring the merger of a Spec (as proposed in Chomsky's 2000 version of the MP which assumes an operation Agree), then the pattern of pied-piping facts above might not be accounted for by the applicability/inapplicability of the movement operation itself, since the latter would not depend on the moved phrase having acquired any particular feature. Thus it would be unclear why the kind of structural position occupied by the wh-morpheme within the moved larger phrase turns out to make a difference for grammaticality. So under the assumption of non-feature-driven movement, the observed differences, such as for instance the well-formedness of a wh-element in the Spec but not in the complement position of the phrase moved to Spec of CP, would have to receive an alternative account.

A possible attempt at such an account, namely, an attempt to derive the pied-piper status of the Spec (of Spec) position in phrases without relying on features, may be based on some independent proposals made with respect to the c-command and binding properties of the Spec position by Kayne (1994), and further elaborated by Hornstein (1995). In Kayne's (1994) Antisymmetry theory, specifiers are taken to be an instance of adjunction. This assumption about specifiers, together with a definition of c-command crucially formulated in terms of exclusion (see (48), Kayne (1994: 24), has the consequence that a specifier will c-command out of the phrase it is the specifier of. In contrast a complement, as before, will not c-command out of its phrase.
(48) X c-commands Y iff X and Y are categories and X excludes Y and every category that dominates X dominates Y.

This will immediately account, for example, for the traditionally problematic cases of bound interpretation of the pronouns (discussed by Reinhart 1983a: 177) in examples like Everyone’s mother thinks he's a genius, or Nobody 's students should respect him , where the quantifier appears in Spec of the subject DP. It will predict the contrast with the unavailability of a bound interpretation for the pronoun in otherwise similar cases when the quantifier is in complement position within the subject DP, as in cases like A small part of every article undermined it , or The election of no one to the Hall of Fame hindered his career (from Hornstein 1995: 107). Now notice that the above assumption, namely, that specifiers, and no other positions in the phrase are able to c-command, and hence bind, some element out of that phrase could potentially provide a non-feature-based account for the specifier vs. complement distinction between pied-pipers of wh-moved phrases. The reason is that irrespective of the issue of wh-feature-checking on C, the wh-operator dominated by the phrase moved to Spec of CP position, such as, e.g., whose in Whose article have you read? needs to bind a variable; it needs to bind a corresponding trace within the IP. Assuming the copy theory of movement, such a ‘trace’ would indeed be available within the lower copy of the moved phrase. Whether this trace can or cannot be bound by the wh-operator dominated by the pied-piped phrase in Spec of CP depends now on whether the position of the wh-operator is such that it c-commands out of the Spec of CP, and hence binds the trace within the IP-internal copy. Assuming, crucially, that no additional (covert) raising of the wh-operator itself is stipulated, a wh-operator appearing in the Spec position of the pied-piped phrase will still be able to bind the corresponding trace in the copy, whereas a wh-operator occurring as a complement of the same phrase will clearly fail to satisfy the requirement of binding the trace in IP, due to failure of c-command.

However, some immediate empirical problems arise in relation to this notion of c-command and its use as an alternative to feature-inheritance accounts for the observed distinctions between positions of wh-pied-pipers vs. wh-non-pied-pipers within phrases. One of these is the fact that, based on Kayne's (1994) notions of specifier and c-command (48), DP specifiers would be expected to give rise to Condition C effects (in the sense of Chomsky's 1981 Binding Theory), namely, disjointness of reference in cases such as (49), and strong crossover, rather than merely mild weak crossover, effects in cases such as (50a). But the (underlined) specifiers of the DPs in (49) and (50a) in fact fail to induce Condition C and strong crossover effects. The absence of strong crossover is demonstrated by the relative acceptability judgment on (50a) contrasting with an uncontroversial strong crossover case (50b) (on the variability and mildness of weak crossover effects manifested by restrictive relative clauses such as (50a), see Lasnik and Stowell 1991).
(49) [Hisi mother] thinks that Johni is a genius.

(50)
a. ??the girl whoi [[heri brother] has hit ti]
b. *the girl [whosei brother] [shei has hit [ti [ ]]]

The facts in (49–50) thus raise serious doubts about these specifiers of DP being able to c-command into the clause, and, more generally, about the claim that specifiers can c-command outside of the maximal XP that they are specifiers of. Incidentally, in contrast to this ‘c-command out of Spec’ proposal, the feature-inheritance account formulated in (43) for pied-piping may also provide a way to approach the problematic discrepancy noted here between the variable-binding behavior of quantificational specifiers (as in Everyone's mother thinks that he is a genius), on the one hand, and the lack of A-binding behavior of non-quantificational specifiers (see (49)), on the other. A potential account reconciling the two structurally parallel cases may be based on the reasonable assumption that while operator features – such as [wh] or [Distributive] – can be freely inherited by the dominating XP via the Spec–Head configuration (as in (47)), referential properties of a DP in Spec, such as those relevant for Condition C effects, cannot be inherited since the dominating DP has independent referential properties of its own.

Another empirical problem arising with respect to the purely operator binding-based (i.e., c-command-based) account of the pied-piping generalizations (45) considered above involves the unexpected discrepancy manifested by adjuncts (modifiers) of DP between the possibility of binding a pronoun and being a pied-piper (see (51a, b)); this is in contrast to the parallel we noted in the case of specifiers (being both binders of pronouns outside of DP and pied-pipers of DP) and complements (being neither binders of pronouns outside of DP nor pied-pipers). While in (51a) the adjunct in the DP seems to be able to bind a pronoun outside its phrase, in a parallel configuration in the embedded clause of (51b), pied-piping by the same adjunct in DP is still not acceptable.

(51)
a. [Someone from every small town] hates it. (Hornstein 1995: 107)
b. *We wondered [[someone from which small town/where] Bill met].

Some general questions to consider regarding this alternative, non-feature-based, account explored above are these. Is it actually sufficient for a fuller range of pied-piping cases, and, in particular, for wh-adjuncts (see the contrast in (51a, b)), which were shown to act systematically as non-pied-pipers? Are the assumptions made earlier regarding the way operator–variable chains are created independently supported? Do they indeed make the feature-inheritance hypothesis of pied-piping redundant, or do these two mechanisms coexist, at least in some of the constructions? Answers to these questions would need to be established based on further investigation and broader theoretical considerations, most of which are beyond the scope of this study.

Returning to the main line of investigation of the core pied-piping generalizations (45), namely, to the one based on the hypothesis of feature-driven movement together with feature ‘inheritance’ via the Spec–Head relation such as formulated in (47), let us consider a related empirical issue not addressed so far. Other things being equal, the proposal predicts that all specifiers will be able to pied-pipe the phrase they are specifiers of. However, Webelhuth (1992, p. 133), in his influential work on pied-piping, calls attention to a set of facts that pose a particularly striking problem for this prediction. It involves the pied-piping behavior of English gerundive nominals with a wh-element in the Spec of DP position, and their contrast with parallel non-gerundive DPs, such as derived nominals, whose lexical head is N (such data were originally observed by Ross (1986: section 4.4.2)). After presenting the relevant facts (see (52–53)), we will discuss some major aspects of Webelhuth's theory of pied-piping which enabled him to derive this phenomenon, as well as could be extended to some of the other known pied-piping generalizations.

(52)
a. The boy [whose loud playing of the piano] I disliked was a student.
b. *The boy [whose playing the piano loudly] I disliked was a student.

(53)
a. I wonder [whose harsh attack on Dukakis] the Democratic voters resented most.
b. *I wonder [whose harshly attacking Dukakis] the Democratic voters resented most.

As shown by the unacceptability of (52b) and (53b), DPs that contain gerundive nominals cannot get pied-piped by their wh-specifier. This is a puzzling phenomenon in light of the fact that specifiers were found to be the prototypical pied-pipers, and the theoretical proposals outlined above had conceptually plausible ways of incorporating this (apparent) generalization. The impossibility of pied-piping manifested by gerundive nominals is more surprising than some other known deviations from the core generalizations given in (45), since unlike, for instance, the case of PPs being pied-piped by complements of P, in cases like (52b−53b) we are dealing with a DP, which is the very category that provided the primary motivation for the pied-piping generalizations. Notice also that their derived nominal counterparts in (52a) and (53a), i.e., parallel DPs but, crucially, exhibiting a lexical N as their head, do get pied-piped by the same wh-specifier (whose).

In view of these facts, Webelhuth (1992: ch. 4) develops the hypothesis that the crucial distinction between specifiers (of non-clausal categories) that are pied-pipers and those that are non-pied-pipers is a consequence of the theta criterion. In fact, Webelhuth proposes and derives the following broader descriptive generalization within his modular approach to pied-piping.
(54) A theta-marked phrase is not a pied-piper.

This hypothesis has obvious potential consequences also for the (non-)pied-piper status of complements, but here we will concentrate on (a) how (54) itself is claimed to be derived from Webelhuth's feature percolation or projection mechanism in interaction with principles of the GB theory, and (b) how it is claimed to account for the gerund–non-gerund contrast with respect to pied-piping by specifiers. (We will return to the consequences of (54) for complements in section 4.4.)

Webelhuth's proposed account of pied-piping is presented in the general context of his theory of syntactic saturation, more specifically, of the projection of the complementation, specification, and modification relations. In this broader framework dealing with the projection of syntactic properties in phrase structure, he also postulates conventions of feature percolation or inheritance (similarly to Koopman 1997 and Koopman and Szabolcsi 2000). However, unlike the more restrictive exclusively Spec–Head relation-based mechanism in (47) above, Webelhuth's theory stipulates that (operator) features can be inherited not only from specifiers but also from complements. Notice that since no features are assumed to be inherited under the modification relation in Webelhuth's theory, the fact that modifiers can never be pied-pipers is predicted in this system too. What is relevant for us at this point is that specifiers are assumed to be able to percolate their features to their mother nodes, unless the head projection of the phrase (i.e., X′) has that particular feature (possibly inherited from the complement). Importantly, the descriptive generalization (54) is based on the output representations of this feature-percolation process being ‘filtered’ by independent principles of UG, and, in particular, the Theta Criterion; Webelhuth's formulation of the relevant principles makes use of the notion of ‘syntactic argument’, which in turn involves the notion ‘operator feature’ (crucially, the latter is used also in the definition of ‘syntactic operator’).

li.p: The Theta Criterion (Webelhuth 1992: 148)

row.entry: Every syntactic argument occurs in exactly one chain that terminates in a theta position.
Every theta position terminates a chain that is headed by exactly one syntactic argument.

li.p: α is a syntactic argument only if

row.entry: α does not carry any operator features.

li.p: α is an operator feature iff α ∈ {[+WH], [+Rel]}.

subsection.p: Based on the above assumptions, Webelhuth's account for the (alleged) generalization (54) goes as follows. The basic condition for a phrase to get pied-piped (under A-bar movements, like wh-movement, which his discussion is concerned with) is that it has to receive an operator feature by percolation from its specifier or complement. So in order to be a pied-piper, a specifier (say the DP whose) would need to percolate an operator feature ([+WH]) up to its mother node (e.g., to the nominals in (52–53)). But no specifier or complement that is able to do that, namely, no specifier or complement that carries an operator feature, can be a member of a theta chain according to Webelhuth's formulation. The reason is that the Theta Criterion (55) requires that heads of theta chains be syntactic arguments, and according to his definition of syntactic argument in (56), a syntactic argument must not carry any operator feature. Thus, he concludes that no phrase that receives a theta role can be a pied-piper (since it cannot bear an operator feature without violating the Theta Criterion).

Given these assumptions, Webelhuth accounts for the observed contrast in the pied-piping options of DPs with gerundives vs. DPs with lexical NPs on the basis of the independently motivated (though not uncontroversial) claim that, while the specifier of a gerundive DP is theta-marked, the specifier of a derived nominal, or any other non-gerundive DP, crucially, is not theta-marked. Webelhuth supports his claim about this theta-marking distinction between gerunds and non-gerunds by observations such as for instance the contrast between *[yesterday's attacking Dukakis] and [yesterday's attack on Dukakis] (for further relevant discussion of theta-marking in nominals, see, e.g., Abney 1987; Grimshaw 1990; Kratzer 1996). So the unacceptability of the pied-piping of gerunds by a wh-Spec illustrated in (52b) and (53b) is attributed by Webelhuth to a violation of the Theta Criterion; the external theta role assigned by the gerund is associated with no well-formed theta chain (due to the lack of a syntactic argument heading the chain).

The way generalization (54) follows in Webelhuth's system is not very natural conceptually; for instance, the reference to “not carrying any operator features” in the definition of “syntactic argument” (see (56c)) is quite ad hoc, since apart from aiming to derive (54), it may just as well be replaced by ‘not being a syntactic operator’ (being a syntactic operator and being an element carrying an operator feature are crucially kept distinct in the proposed system). If (56c) were restated this way, the Theta Criterion would no longer have the consequence that a theta-marked phrase cannot be a pied-piper. Thus the real issue to consider is whether the generalization in (54) is correct empirically, i.e., whether theta-marked phrases indeed never act as pied-pipers. In section 4.4 we will return to the issue of the putative correlation between theta-marking and being/not being a pied-piper, in the context of a discussion of pied-piping by complements.

Regarding the specific account Webelhuth's hypothesis offers for the contrast between gerundive and non-gerundive nominals, one relevant consideration in favor of finding an alternative, non-theta-theory-based account (see the discussion of (58) below) is that the degree of unacceptability of examples like (52b) and (53b) reported by speakers is very different; it is far less severe than in other cases standardly attributed to violations of the Theta Criterion, specifically, e.g., when a theta chain is headed by an expletive.

Finally, consider an additional set of relevant observations about pied-piping of gerunds, cited in an unrelated context by Culicover (1999: 97); these data represent judgments distinct in a suggestive way from those in (52b−53b):

(58)
a. *[Who solving the problem] were you thinking about?
Cf. We were thinking about [Mary solving the problem]
b. [Whose solving the problem] were you thinking about?
c. [Whose solving of the problem] were you thinking about?

The acceptability of pied-piping in (58b) indicated by Culicover contradicts the judgments that Webelhuth cites for parallel gerunds with a possessive (whose) as their specifier. What is more revealing is that gerunds do exhibit a prohibition against being pied-piped by a wh-specifier in Culicover's dialect too, as shown by (58a). However, this holds only for accusative-marked subjects of gerunds but not for the possessive ones. This difference represented in (58a) vs. (58b, c) suggests that at least in this variety of English, and perhaps more generally, the non-pied-piper behavior of specifiers of gerunds may be related to these specifiers occurring lower in the functional layer of the nominal than the Spec of the top (DP) projection.

Possessive specifiers of non-gerundive nominals occur in all dialects as the Spec of the top functional projection of the nominal (DP), hence their ability to percolate their wh-feature to the DP node. In contrast, at least accusative marked, i.e., non-possessive, specifiers of gerunds, and possibly in some dialects also morphologically possessive specifiers of gerunds, would appear as the Spec of a functional projection that is not the topmost one in the nominal. Specifically, either gerunds have an additional outer layer of projection compared to non-gerundive DPs (as suggested in Kayne 1994: 135, n. 18), or the specifier who/whose of gerunds is a Spec of some functional complement of D. In either case, the wh-feature of such a specifier could not be inherited by the maximal nominal phrase under the restrictive feature inheritance mechanism based on Spec–Head agreement.

subsection.heading: 4.3 Some other effects
subsection.p: This section will address two types of pied-piping phenomenon, introduced earlier in sections 3.1.1 and 3.1.2, which prima facie constitute major deviations, in two opposing directions, from the core pied-piping generalizations and the corresponding theoretical proposals presented in section 4.2 above. The discussion will demonstrate, however, that, arguably, each of these cases is attributable to the effects of independent factors and does not stem from the pied-piping mechanism itself.

subsection.heading: 4.3.1 Relative clauses and the topicalization proposal
subsection.p: As shown in section 3.1.1, English (lexically headed) relatives, and in particular non-restrictive relatives, seem to permit a curious, much more extensive pied-piping process than what one finds in other wh-constructions and in other Germanic languages. Among the relevant data we find, for instance, complements of DPs and APs that are able to pied-pipe their phrase (see (59), reproduced from section 3.1.1). Such pied-piping is not possible in the rest of wh-constructions (wh-interrogatives, exclamatives, etc.), and indeed it would be excluded both under the Spec–Head agreement based feature inheritance hypothesis (47) of Koopman (1997), and also under Webelhuth's (1992) system (in the latter, due to the theta marked nature of these complements).

(59)
a. Reports [the height of the lettering on the covers of which] the government prescribes should be abolished.
b. He is a linguist [articles by whom] the editors always reject.
c. This is the kind of woman [proud of whom] I could never be.

In spite of the fact that this type of data include the cases that led Ross (1986) to propose the Pied-Piping Convention in the first place, already as early as Emonds's (1976) it was suggested that these particular instances of apparent pied-piping constitute a special, stylistically marked phenomenon which, contrary to Ross's view, should in fact not be taken to be derived by the same grammatical device as the other cases of wh-pied-piping, which occur irrespective of construction type. Specifically, Emonds (1976: 187) claimed that these cases (like (59)) fall outside the domain of grammar proper and proposed that the pied-piping processes involved in them belong to the stylistic component (as defined in Banfield 1973). As a reason for this claim, he points to the “marginal” acceptability status of this particular subtype of pied-piping data. (On the occurrence of such pied-piping in non-restrictive and restrictive relatives, see the discussion of examples (21) in section 3.1.1, and for the proposal of topicalization as the source for these, see Emonds 1979.)

Later, in the context of his general account of pied-piping presented within the framework of the GB theory, Webelhuth (1992) followed a conceptually similar path regarding these stylistically marked pied-piping cases. Recall that pied-piping of a phrase by its theta-marked complement (as, e.g., in (59)) or specifier was hypothesized by Webelhuth to be excluded, as we noted in our discussion of gerunds in section 4.2. Webelhuth's considerations in favor of analyzing cases like (59) as irrelevant for the theory of pied-piping, and hence in favor of maintaining his pied-piping theory excluding them, were the following: (a) the phenomenon is English-particular, i.e., is limited to only one among all the Germanic languages; (b) it is attested in only one construction type, namely, in relative clauses (and for some speakers only in non-restrictive ones); and (c) it belongs to a “literary” style of English and is felt to be “foreign to natural colloquial speech” (pointed out by Webelhuth, citing Jespersen). Given his conclusion that the pied-piping mechanism should not be extended to derive these “unusual” cases, to avoid the obvious overgeneration problem, Webelhuth develops an account for these stylistically marked sentences with apparent pied-piping based on a topicalization analysis, suggested originally by Emonds (1979). According to Webelhuth, these phenomena fall outside the core grammar (in the sense of Chomsky's 1981 core vs. periphery). He claims that the large phrase containing the wh-relative pronoun undergoes topicalization, and furthermore that this wh-word occurring within this preposed phrase receives interpretation as an indexical pronoun in these “exceptional” constructions. This option is available, he claims, due to the basic similarity in the semantic effects of relative and indexical pronouns (both may involve the formation of an open sentence and its predication of a referent). Thus the analysis draws a parallel between the relation of the relative pronoun (whom) to the head of the relative (his wife) in (60a) and that of the personal pronoun (her) to its discourse antecedent (his wife) in (60b) (see Webelhuth 1992: 131).
