It should be noted here that Webelhuth's proposal fails to offer an account for the impossibility of using a non-wh pronoun (her) instead of whom in English relative clauses such as (60a), and, even more significantly, the impossibility of using a wh-form (whom) as an alternative for the definite pronoun (her) in cases such as (60b) (the latter option appears to be excluded cross-linguistically). These distributional facts would need to be regarded as manifestations of some hitherto unspecified purely morphological variation in the realization of pronouns.

(60)
a. His wife [proud of whom] he has never been.
b. His wife is intelligent. But [proud of her] he has never been.

Under this proposal, the reason why such “exceptional” pied-piping may arise in the case of relatives but not, for instance, in interrogatives is that the wh-words in the latter are logical operators that restrict the range of a variable, not variables that get bound. Hence they are not able to take on the function of anaphoric pronouns, in contrast to relative pronouns, for which this is more feasible.

As for the observed preference – and, according to Emonds (1979, 1985), the actual limitation – for this kind of pied-piping to occur only in non-restrictive, rather than restrictive, relatives (see (21a, b, c)), there are at least two approaches to be considered. Assuming the topicalization-based account of non-core pied-piping, Emonds (1979) attributes its non-occurrence in restrictive relatives directly to the (alleged) root nature of topicalization (on root transformations, see Emonds (1976) and chapter 23). Since under his approach non-restrictive relatives are root clauses, he predicts that these, but not restrictive relatives, will permit topicalization and hence the occurrence of the above pied-piping phenomenon. Another proposal that can draw the relevant distinction between non-restrictive and restrictive relatives, and moreover, do so without resorting to the problematic claim of topicalization being a root phenomenon, may be based on Lasnik and Stowell's (1991) findings regarding weak crossover effects in various A-bar movement constructions. They observe a contrast between the presence of weak crossover effects – i.e., the unavailability of a bound variable construal for a pronoun – in restrictive relatives (as e.g. in the/every mani whoi hisi mother loves ti) and the absence of weak crossover in non-restrictive relatives (as, e.g., in Geraldi, whoi hisi mother loves ti). Crucially for us, their study motivates an account for the presence vs. absence of weak crossover effects in different A-bar constructions that is based on the logical status of the local A-bar binder of the pronoun: only a true quantifier (ranging over a possibly non-singleton set) gives rise to weak crossover effects, while non-quantificational A-bar binders do not. Given this, notice first that the observed inability of the wh-element of non-restrictive relatives to induce weak crossover effects reinforces Webelhuth's proposal of deriving the non-core pied-piping cases under discussion from the pronoun-like, i.e., non-quantificational, nature of the wh-element involved, though only as far as non-restrictive relatives are concerned. Furthermore, in light of (a) the presence of weak crossover effects in restrictive relatives, indicating under Lasnik and Stowell's theory that the wh-element in the latter is in fact quantificational and (b) Webelhuth's topicalization-based analysis for pied-piping cases as in (59–60) above, we can make sense of the contrast observed by Emonds between the availability of non-core pied-piping in non-restrictive relatives and its un-availability in restrictive relatives.

In sum, the proposed analysis derives this exceptional pied-piping construction, not as a true relative clause involving (pied-piping) wh-movement, but by the independent operation of topicalization, and, crucially, assigns an interpretation to the resulting structure in analogy to sentences with anaphoric pronouns. As the reason for their stylistically highly marked nature, Webelhuth points to the mismatch that arises between “the form of these structures as relative clauses and their interpretation, which applies a semantic rule of discourse anaphora to relative pronouns that usually exclusively fall into the domain of sentence grammar” (Webelhuth 1992: 132).

As evidence for his topicalization proposal, Webelhuth mentions the prediction that if topicalization of a phrase is impossible in a particular clause, then that phrase will not to be able to undergo stylistically marked pied-piping in the corresponding relative clause. This prediction seems to be borne out indeed, as shown by his data demonstrating the correlation between the unacceptability of topicalization in examples like *[To leave] I want and the unacceptability of the corresponding relative clause *his wife [to leave whom] he wanted (see Webelhuth 1992: 131). However, beyond the above type of correlation that may suggest that topicalization is involved in the appearance of stylistically marked pied-piping in relatives, the proposed account, as it stands, makes some broader, and more problematic predictions as well.

Webelhuth's hypothesis of the interpretation of the relative pronoun in the preposed phrase taking it to be an indexical pronoun with a discourse antecedent suggests that no extra structural or other grammatical constraints will limit its possible positions within the topicalized phrase, and it will occur as freely as an ordinary pronoun would (as, e.g., in (60a) vs. (60b)). Thus, based on the proposal, one would expect that in English any phrase that (a) can undergo topicalization in a clause and (b) contains a relative wh-word should be able to undergo the exceptional pied-piping process under discussion, resulting in a well-formed relative clause in the literary style. However, contrary to this expectation, a variety of phenomena have been observed in the literature indicating the existence of further clear and specific restrictions of an obviously grammatical nature that determine the acceptability status of stylistically marked pied-piping. Thus, consider for instance the contrasts between (61a, b) and (62a–d) from Nanni and Stillings (1978), involving pied-piping data of the stylistically marked kind where it is a preposed clausal constituent, such as an infinitival (vs. finite) CP, a gerundive or an absolute, that contains the relative pronoun (the position of the relative pronoun is varied). Incidentally, notice that these data would uniformly be excluded by Ross's (1986) formulation of the Pied-Piping Convention (given in section 2.1).

(61)
a. The elegant parties, [to be invited to one of which] was a privilege . . .
b. The strange man [upon seeing whom] Mary called the police . . .

(62)
a. *The men, [for whom to be invited to the elegant parties] was a privilege . . .
b. *The strange man [upon John's seeing whom] Mary called the police . . .
c. *The elegant parties, [for us to be admitted to one of which] was a privilege . . .
d. *The car [(the idea) that their son might drive which] surprised them . . .

The descriptive generalizations that emerge from the above data are that the relative pronoun in the preposed ‘pied-piped’ constituents cannot be a subject, but seems to have to be a complement, and that the preposed constituent itself cannot have a lexical subject, and possibly in addition it cannot have finite Tense (as suggested by Cinque 1982 and Kayne 1984a: 86).

Such data are not discussed at all in Webelhuth (1992), even though the existence of this type of clausal pied-piping effects are actually predicted in his system, since clausal arguments as well as adjuncts (such as the ones preposed in (61) and (62)) are able to undergo topicalization. He considers only clausal pied-piping outside of the context of stylistically marked relatives, and based on that concludes that it does not exist in Germanic (see our discussion in sections 3.3 and in 4.5). The apparently ‘pied-piped’ clauses above indeed involve no true instances of pied-piping by wh-movement; being stylistically marked and construction specific, they fall under the hypothesis presented above for cases like (59). What is relevant in the present context is that their existence, and, crucially, some specific structural constraints on them (illustrated above) were observed and analyzed in the earlier literature, in particular by Nanni and Stillings (1978), Cinque (1982), Hendrick (1982), Kayne (1984a: 186), and Ishihara (1984). Furthermore, it is worth noting that Italian, a language that has been shown in Cinque (1982) to exhibit pied-piping phenomena in relatives parallel to the stylistically marked cases of English mentioned earlier, also turns out to manifest the structure-based grammaticality contrasts with respect to ‘pied-piped’ elements in relatives shown above for English.

While the facts in (61–62) demonstrate that the interpretation of the relative pronoun (occurring within a topicalized phrase) in analogy to indexical pronouns proposed by Webelhuth is clearly not sufficient to account for the stylistically marked pied-piping phenomenon, the source of the constraints manifested is not well understood. There have been several attempts in the literature to treat (at least part of) the relevant phenomena, among them Kayne's (1984a: 185) proposal based on defining a ‘wh-phrase’ that can occupy the COMP (i.e., [Spec, CP]) of the relative clause in terms of the notion of g-projection set of a wh-phrase, Cinque's (1982) anaphor hypothesis, Ishihara's (1984) account based on LF-raising of the wh-word and the ECP, and Safir's (1986) proposal of LF-raising of the relative wh-word to satisfy a locality requirement on R-binding by the head of the relative. However, no comprehensive adequate account has emerged so far, and this stylistically marked pied-piping phenomenon with its pattern of robust grammaticality constraints obviously calls for further investigation of the underlying mechanism(s) that may be responsible for it.

subsection.heading: 4.3.2 Free relatives and the identification of a pro head
subsection.p: The wh-pied-piping phenomena in (finite) free relatives introduced with respect to English in section 3.1.2 represent another initially surprising case of deviation from the pied-piping generalization stated in (45). This deviation involves the opposite direction from the deviation found in the case of overtly headed stylistically marked relatives (discussed in section 4.3.1): the possible range of pied-piping effects in such free relatives is more restricted than what one would expect of pied-piping by a wh-element based on the other wh-constructions. Specifically, the latter construction type was claimed in Grosu (1989) not to permit pied-piping even by a wh-specifier (of specifier) of a DP, as shown in (24); in contrast, such pied-piping occurs freely both in interrogatives, and overtly headed relatives.

Notice that the unacceptability of cases like (24b, c) cannot be attributed to some limitation on the ‘size’ of the preposed wh-constituent permitted in free relatives, in view of the perfect acceptability of examples such as (63), where the wh-element is the head of the preposed ‘large’ DP:
(63) Mary will buy [[whichever portraits of friends of hers] we can find t for her].

Neither can we dismiss the observed extra restriction on pied-piping in free relatives by attributing the observed unacceptability simply to a Case mismatch, as, e.g., between the possessive form whose in (24b, c) and the free relative itself, the latter needing to be accusative (in (24b)) or nominative (in (24c)). The reason is that the same anti-pied-piping effect shown in (24) is attested also (a) in cases where the Case matching requirement known to hold in free relatives is clearly satisfied (as in the German example (64) cited in Grosu 1994: 30), as well as (b) in free relatives permitting non-matching, which occur in particular positions in languages such as Romanian (see example (65), cited by Grosu 1994: 34).

(64)
*Ich bedarf [proGen
[wessenGen
Bildes]Gen
du auch bedarfst]. German
I need whose picture you also need
‘I need (the person) whose picture you also need.’

(65)
*[Al cui cîine muşcǎ trecǎtorii] trebuie amendat. Romanian
whose dog bites the-passers-by must fined
‘(The person) whose dog bites those who walk by must be fined.’

According to Grosu (1994: ch. 3), this anti-pied-piping phenomenon is found universally across languages in realis free relatives, and is limited to this construction type. Since it cannot be dismissed as some peripheral idiosyncratic phenomenon, the question arising is, Does this apparent inability of the wh-specifier to pied-pipe its phrase (i.e., the DP) indicate a need to revise the general feature-inheritance mechanism based on the Spec–Head relation (see (47)) postulated in Koopman's (1997) and Webelhuth's (1992) system as the central mechanism underlying pied-piping, or, alternatively, is there some independent factor that creates the special limitations on the output of pied-piping in free relatives? In view of the fact that the apparent impossibility of pied-piping of DP by its specifier is limited to a specific subclass of free relatives (in contrast to all other varieties of wh-constructions), it seems obvious that the more promising option of the two is the latter one, that is to say, finding an account that can derive the phenomenon from independently motivated properties of realis free relatives and general principles of UG, while leaving the pied-piping mechanism itself unaffected.

This was the kind of approach taken by Grosu (1994: ch. 3). In the context of a comprehensive study of the various subtypes of free relative, Grosu developed an account the essence of which is that the wh-element coindexed with the pro head of the free relative needs to locally identify this pro, but being in the Spec of the pied-piped DP, rather than being the Spec of CP itself, it is unable to do so. Grosu's proposal is based on the widely accepted assumptions that (a) realis, i.e., finite, free relatives have a phonologically null head, pro, and (b) the feature-content of pro needs to be identified. It is argued in the study that the only possible identifier for this pro is internal to the free relative; it is the wh-phrase (within the Spec of CP) that serves as its antecedent. Furthermore, the relation between the pro and its identifier in the clause is claimed to be subject to a strict locality requirement. Specifically, it is assumed that only the CP, i.e. the free relative itself, is local enough structurally to be able to identify the pro head, where identification is assumed to involve the set of phi-features of the wh-antecedent being conveyed to pro. Given this, the (anti-)pied-piping effects observed in free relatives above can be derived directly from the existence of a pro head in these structures in conjunction with the same feature-inheritance mechanism that we presented as the core mechanism underlying pied-piping in section 4.2 (based on Webelhuth 1992 and Koopman 1997).

In order for the identifying features of the wh-antecedent to reach the actual local identifier (the CP) according to Grosu's proposal, feature inheritance and/or percolation needs to take place; features of the wh-antecedent can be transmitted to C by Spec–Head agreement and from C to CP by percolation. Thus any case where the Spec of CP position is occupied by the wh-antecedent itself, as in (63), satisfies the requirement of pro identification. But, crucially, pro identification seems to fail in cases where the wh-antecedent of pro occurs in the Spec (of Spec) position of the preposed DP, as in (24b, c). The reason for this under Grosu's proposal is that the phi-features of the wh-specifier (whose) needed for the identification of pro cannot get to the entire DP occupying Spec of CP by Spec–Head agreement because the DP itself has inherent features of the same kind as the wh-specifier, and an arguably independently motivated property of feature inheritance blocks transmission of these features. (A similar convention of priority of feature-percolation from the head over transmission of the same feature from the specifier is postulated in Webelhuth's 1992: 147 system in relation to operator features; this is of empirical significance with respect to his account of CP-pied-piping, to be discussed in section 4.5). Since the phi-features of the wh-specifier of DP cannot reach DP nor, consequently, CP, they fail to identify the head pro. (It would also need to be the case that C, in contrast to D, has no comparable features that would block transmission of the identifying features from its Spec in cases like (63).)

In sum, it appears that it is not pied-piping of a DP by its wh-specifier that is ruled out for some reason in realis free relatives. Rather, the unacceptability of free relatives like (24b, c), (64), and (65) is attributable to the presence of an improperly identified pro. Notice that in contrast to the case of phi-feature transmission, wh-feature transmission via the Spec–Head relation to DP, as used in the derivation of wh-pied-piping itself, would pose no problem of ‘blocking’ since this feature is not an inherent feature of D in cases such as [whose picture]). Supporting evidence for the pro-identification account of anti-pied-piping effects in realis free relatives is provided by Grosu's (1994: 142) observation regarding the contrast with irrealis/infinitival free relatives. The latter have various properties indicating that they are bare CPs, i.e., that they have no head pro. As expected, based on the above hypothesis for deriving the anti-pied-piping effects, these in realis free relatives turn out to manifest no such effects (see, e.g., (66) from Romanian); they in fact display the same pattern of pied-piping phenomena as infinitival embedded questions do.

(66)
Maria nu are [la fotografia cui sǎ se uite]. Romanian
Maria not has at picture-the whose SP self look
‘Maria doesn't have (anyone) at whose picture to look.’

subsection.heading: 4.4 PP pied-piping
subsection.p: The widely attested phenomenon of pied-piping of PPs by their complements (as shown with respect to wh-movement in section 3.3) seems to represent a substantive problem for the basic pied-piping generalization stated in (45). Complements of other categories fail to act as pied-pipers while the complements of P can, and in a large number of languages must, pied-pipe the PP. Combined with the fact that this takes place irrespective of construction type, indicates that the phenomenon can potentially have important implications regarding the adequacy of suggested mechanisms of pied-piping (such as the feature percolation mechanism being limited to Spec–Head agreement and projection from the head) and/or regarding constraints affecting its output (such as Webelhuth's 1992 formulation of the Theta Criterion and the notion of syntactic argument).

The question of how the complement of P can act as a pied-piper for the PP has been addressed in the literature by several different proposals, though at this point none of these seem to be supported by truly compelling empirical evidence. These proposals – to be outlined below – fall into two basic subtypes. One general direction, represented by Webelhuth's (1992: sect. 4.4.3) and Grosu's (1994: sect. 1.4.1) proposals, involves the crucial claim that the category P is not a lexical head at all but is uniformly a non-theta-marking functional category, parallel to inflectional categories and in particular to Case. Such theories also presuppose a somewhat less restrictive version of the feature percolation/inheritance mechanism than the one outlined in (47), assumed for pied-piping in work such as Koopman (1997) and Koopman and Szabolcsi (2000). The other direction of thought, manifested for instance in Kayne's (1994) and Koopman's (1997) work, involves the internal syntax of PPs and in particular the idea that what looks like a complement of P is actually not in complement, but in Spec position, at least in derived structure.

Webelhuth's assumption about operator-feature percolation (see section 4.2) permits features to percolate up to their mother node not only from specifiers, but crucially also from complements. Given this, his system has no problem predicting that wh-complements of P will be able to pied-pipe the PP. However it would also predict, other things being equal, that wh-complements of other categories, e.g., N, A, or V, will be pied-pipers as well. To avoid this incorrect prediction, Webelhuth proposed to draw the relevant distinction between complements of P and complements of the other (lexical) heads from the conjunction of the following two assumptions: (a) a particular formulation of the Theta Criterion making crucial reference to the head of a theta chain not carrying any operator feature (see (55) and (56) above), from which he derived the generalization (stated as (54)) that no theta-marked phrase can be a pied-piper, and (b) the claim that while N, A, and V theta-mark their complement, the category P is not a theta-marker, i.e., Ps, including the semantically contentful ones, take complements yet do not assign theta roles to them. These assumptions, if tenable, would yield a distinction between P-complements being pied-pipers and complements of theta-marking heads (claimed to be V, N, and A) not being pied-pipers. The operator feature [wh] could percolate up from a wh-complement in all phrase-types under Webelhuth's theory; however, due to the way the Theta Criterion is stated, all cases of pied-piping by complements that are theta-marked by the head would be ruled out as Theta Criterion violations (similarly to pied-piping by specifiers of gerundive DPs discussed in section 4.2).

Webelhuth's arguments for the claim that the category P is never a theta-marker for its complement – at most it can ‘solicit’ a theta role from some theta-marking head – are based on observed differences between prepositions and the other lexical heads, and on some parallels between prepositons and (oblique) inflectional Case affixes. He notes, for instance, the functional equivalence between idiosyncratically selected Ps and case affixes in languages like German, both used, according to Webelhuth, as purely formal markers (e.g., the verbs begegnen ‘meet’ and finden ‘find’ require dative or accusative case-marking on their internal argument, and parallel to this, some other verbs, e.g., hoffen ‘hope’ and abhängen ‘depend’, require particular prepositions as formal markers for their internal argument, namely auf ‘on’ and von ‘of’, respectively). Other properties pointed out by Webelhuth are the tendency of Ps, in contrast to members of other lexical categories, to lose their meaning in the course of diachronic change, and the fact that while the theta-marking heads N, V, and A can all be stranded by their complement across languages (for instance in all the Germanic languages), stranding of prepositions by a (non-pronominal) complement is impossible in many languages, including German. The latter cases are claimed to be due to an ECP violation (Chomsky 1986a) that results from P not being a theta-governing lexical head for a trace in its complement position (on alternative accounts of P-stranding, see chapter 51). Based on these and similar observations, he concludes that prepositions are “syntactic heads with the nonthematic marking function of affixes”. (For a detailed study establishing the status of P as a uniformly non-theta-marking functional category, see Botwinik-Rotem 2004.)

Accepting the well-motivated assumption that P is not a theta-assigner, Webelhuth's theory correctly yields the possibility of PP being pied-piped by its complement, while excluding pied-piping by complements of theta-marking V, N, and A heads. However, notice that this approach – in particular the idea of free feature-inheritance from complements, and the filtering of the resulting pied-piping cases only by the Theta Criterion (55–56) – makes a broader, arguably problematic, prediction. Specifically, it predicts (for operator movement cases, such as wh-movement) that for any head X, if X fails to theta-mark its complement YP, then YP will be able to pied-pipe XP. But is this prediction empirically justified?

First of all it appears to face some difficulty already in the case of the category P itself, in light of certain colloquial varieties of English. It is noted by Kayne (1994: 25) that for some speakers, in colloquial register, PP-pied-piping is unacceptable (see Kayne's examples (25), including, e.g., *Nobody knows to what school he goes, *Tell us from where you got that.) If this indeed is a systematic dialect, Webelhuth's view of pied-piping by complements would not provide a plausible way to account for it. Under Webelhuth's theory, one would have to say either that this colloquial dialect has a different feature-percolation mechanism – i.e., a different projection mechanism for the complement relation – prohibiting feature-inheritance from complements, or that Ps in this variety of English are in fact theta-assigners for their complements. Clearly, neither of these are reasonable claims.

A different, more significant kind of counter-evidence for the above prediction is provided by the case of a subset of N heads, and their minimal contrast with locative Ps. Consider the type of nominals – such as a picture of John, the legs of the chair, a gift to Mary – that Grimshaw (1990) refers to as “result” or “simple” nominals. As is argued extensively by Grimshaw, although such Ns are able to take complements, they have no syntactic argument structure, and, crucially for us, are not theta-assigners for their complement. (They contrast with so-called complex event nominals, which are theta-assigners, exhibiting an argument structure similar to Vs.)

Given Grimshaw's (1990) theory, there is no theta-related difference between this set of Ns and Ps to rely on: neither are theta-assigners for their complement. Hence, based on Webelhuth's mechanism of feature percolation, we would expect complements of simple nominals and result nominals to act as pied-pipers for their phrase just like Ps do. As shown by the contrast between (67a, b) and (68a, b), this prediction turns out to be wrong.

(67)
a. *I wonder most pictures of whom John liked.
b. *Tell me a leg of which chair we should try to fix.

(68)
a. I wonder under whom John put some pillows.
b. Tell me near whom you saw a gun.

It is also worth noting here that the choice of locative Ps – rather than idiosyncratic (inflection-like) Ps considered by Webelhuth – is significant for the comparison (67–68) above, since they constitute a more minimal contrast with the Ns being tested than other kinds of P would. Locative Ps are parallel to the Ns involved in that (a) they clearly have semantic content, and (b) they constitute independent binding domains for Condition B effects, i.e., in terms of Reinhart and Reuland's (1993) Reflexivity framework, they, just like Ns, can form a semantic predicate of their own (see the possibility of a pronoun in (69a, b)).

(69)
a. Johni put some pillows under himi/himself.
(Cf. Johni explained Mary to *himi/himself.)
b. Johni liked most pictures of himi/himself.

In view of the pied-piping contrast between complements of result Ns and complements of Ps exhibited by (67) and (68), we can discard the above free feature-percolation approach to pied-piping by complements.

Returning now to Webelhuth's argumentation regarding the parallelism between Ps and inflectional (case-marking) affixes, what it amounts to conceptually comes very close to saying that P is a functional, rather than a lexical, head. Grosu (1994) makes this claim explicitly, and based on it, puts forth an alternative, empirically superior, account of PP-pied-piping by complements. He motivates his conclusion by pointing out various parallelisms between the behavior of Ps and of case affixes, in particular in free relatives in a variety of languages.

Importantly, given his assumption that P is a functional head, i.e., the top layer in the extended projection of N, Grosu's proposed account does not have to rely on the Theta Criterion (as in Webelhuth's version) to exclude feature percolation from complements of V, N, and A, while permitting percolation from complements of P. Instead it utilizes a different feature-percolation mechanism that is more restrictive than the one assumed by Webelhuth. Following Grimshaw (1991), Grosu proposes that aside from Spec–Head agreement, features can percolate up from complements too, but, crucially, only from within the same extended projection, not from outside of it. Hence, no percolation of wh or other features is possible from the complements of lexical heads, for instance to NP (and DP) from the complement of N, or to VP from the complement of V. In contrast, percolation is possible from the NP complement of the functional head D to DP, and, crucially for our case, from the DP-complement of the functional head P to the whole PP, since in these cases, the features involved, namely both the [wh] feature (inducing PP pied-piping under wh-movement) and the phi-features (needed to identify the pro head of free relatives) would be staying within the same single extended projection.

Another type of approach to deriving the pied-piper status of complements of P is proposed in Koopman (1997). This alternative is compatible with an even more restrictive feature-inheritance mechanism, which limits percolation to take place via Spec–Head agreement and only within a single, non-extended, maximal projection, from a head X up to the lowest maximal projection XP (as shown in (47) of section 4.2). Importantly, no feature-percolation from any kind of complement is permitted. Instead, the proposal invokes (strictly local) head movement (see (70)). (Factors like no theta-marking by P, or P having to be a functional rather than a lexical head, play no role in the account).

li.p: Head movement (and Spec–Head agreement):

subsection.p: Koopman's claim is essentially that a complement of P is able to pied-pipe the PP, i.e., the whole extended projection of P, due to this wh-complement coming to occupy actually the Spec of some head Y, which receives the wh-feature from it via Spec–Head agreement; crucially, this head then raises to the head of the extended projection of P, i.e., adjoins to the topmost head (the next head above it), and as a result the latter head, and hence the whole PP, receives the wh-feature (which originated in the complement of P). (For more on the specific assumptions regarding the internal structure and syntax of PPs, see Koopman 2000a.)

A variant of this type of movement-based approach to pied-piping by the complement of P that had been proposed occasionally earlier (see, e.g., Kayne 1994: 25) assumed that in languages that permit or require PP-pied-piping by a complement, the wh-complement undergoes covert movement to the Spec of the top layer of PP. The overt counterpart of the same movement had been assumed to exist too, as an intermediate step in the derivation of P-stranding, which is, as mentioned earlier, required in some versions of colloquial English. (The idea of the complement of P moving to a Spec-like position in PP when being extracted by wh-movement is due originally to Van Riemsdijk's 1978a work on Dutch PPs.)

These movement-based analyses of the pied-piper status of the complement of P do not need to make the problematic connection between the lack of theta-marking and being a pied-piper, as Webelhuth's account does, and, furthermore, they are not forced to claim that P is necessarily a functional head, as under Grosu's proposal. However they would still need to address this question: Are the postulated PP-internal movements unique to this category, and if so, why? If they were not, then one would expect the same option of pied-piping by a complement to arise – as a result of phrase-internal overt/covert movement ‘delivering’ the operator feature of the complement, as in (70) – also in projections of other lexical categories (V, N, A). This however is not attested, at least not in the well-studied Germanic case. Thus the movement postulated in the account of PP-pied-piping would have to be considered unique to this category-type. But then one is still left with the question, What makes the same movements – specifically, the head movement in (70) – available to projections of P and yet unavailable to projections of V, N, or A? A likely answer to this will presumably lead us back to the functional–lexical distinction between P and the other three heads.

subsection.heading: 4.5 Clausal pied-piping
subsection.p: The mechanisms proposed to underlie pied-piping considered in the above subsections, namely, versions of a feature-percolation-based account, as well as the proposal based on c-command (binding, therefore) from the Spec of a phrase to outside of that phrase, would lead us to expect that the Spec position of CP could in principle act as a pied-piper for the CP. The questions for empirical study in this respect, then, are (a) whether Spec of CP indeed can pied-pipe the CP and (b) to the extent that it cannot, in particular languages at least, what the reason for this is.

Notice first that the empirical issue of clausal pied-piping was raised and discussed in the early GB framework with respect to English by Nanni and Stillings (1978) and Ishihara (1984). However, the clausal pied-piping cases these studies discussed were of the stylistically marked variety of pied-piping we discussed in section 4.3.1. These cases are limited to relative-clause constructions whose wh-element occupied an IP-internal argument position; they are not part of normal colloquial English. This construction arguably involves some mechanism other than pied-piping under wh-movement, and is therefore not relevant for the issue of CP-pied-piping (see our discussion in section 4.3.1, based on Webelhuth's (1992) arguments for such cases of apparent pied-piping being derived by topicalization and involving a way of interpreting the wh-relative pronoun that falls outside of core grammar).
Regarding English, Webelhuth concludes that it permits no CP pied-piping, based on the ungrammaticality of the following type of data:

(71)
a. *[Who [John met t]] did Mary know t?
b. *[Who [to talk to t]] did she forget t?
(Webelhuth 1992: 152)

This indeed seems to be correct; English embedded CPs with a wh-element occupying their Spec cannot get pied-piped to the matrix Spec of CP position under wh-movement no matter whether the clause is finite or infinitival. In such cases the wh-element in the lower Spec of CP position has only two options: either it is extracted from the embedded clause (successive cyclic movement), resulting in a matrix question, or it may stay and get interpreted in the embedded CP, provided that the selecting predicate permits an embedded question.

The explanation proposed by Webelhuth appears to attribute the ungrammaticality of examples like (71) to a property of feature percolation we already referred to in section 4.3.2 as part of Grosu's (1994) account for why the specifier of a wh-moved DP in free relatives cannot identify the head pro, in other words, why it cannot percolate its phi-features up to the DP. The relevant assumption is that a particular feature (independently of the value specified for it) that is borne both by a specifier YP and by the head projection X′ of a phrase XP can percolate to XP only from X′; feature percolation from Spec (normally available, via the Spec–Head relation) is blocked in such cases. Thus, according to Webelhuth, pied-piping of a CP by its Spec is excluded whenever the sister node of the Spec, namely C′, is marked for the feature [wh], since then the wh-element in Spec is unable to percolate its wh-operator feature up to the CP, and hence this CP cannot turn into an operator itself; as a result it cannot form a well-formed operator chain with the syntactic variable it binds (i.e., with its own trace) and, consequently, movement of such a CP would be ruled out. The specific stipulation Webelhuth makes in order to account for the (alleged) lack of CP-pied-piping in Germanic languages is that the (embedded) complementizer C is marked [−wh], and it is due to this property of C that the [+wh] feature of the phrase in Spec of CP cannot reach the CP. But in fact, given his particular definition of the notion ‘syntactic operator’, even if the [+wh] feature of the preposed wh-phrase were permitted to percolate up to the CP, the derivation would still fail to result in well-formed CP-pied-piping. As pointed out by Webelhuth (1992: 152), if who in a case like (71a), for instance, were to percolate its operator feature to the CP, then it would cease to qualify as a syntactic operator, and consequently, its trace in the clause would constitute a syntactic variable that is not bound by a syntactic operator, thus violating Webelhuth's (p. 143) version of the Bijection Principle (adapted from Koopman and Sportiche 1982).

However, when we go beyond the Germanic languages, Webelhuth's specific assumptions about the role played by the wh-feature of C and the reference of the Bijection Principle to syntactic operator preventing CP-pied-piping by its Spec appear to be challenged empirically, for instance, by the case of Basque as reported by in Ortiz de Urbina (1990). (See also Cole 1982a on CP-pied-piping in Imbabura Quechua.) Basque interrogatives exhibit wh-movement to the left periphery of the clause to a position that is immediately followed by the finite verbal element (allegedly a V2 phenomenon). Furthermore, Basque has two distinct overt complementizers; one -(e)n for interrogative, i.e., [+wh] complements, and another, -(e)la, for non-interrogative, i.e., [−wh], complements. Consider now the following data suggesting the existence of CP-pied-piping, pointed out by Ortiz de Urbina with respect to Basque interrogatives (corresponding to his examples (15i) and (17)):

(72)
[Nor
etorriko d-ela bihar] esan diozu Mireni? Basque
who come Aux-that tomorrow said Aux Mary-Dat
‘Who have you told Mary will come tomorrow?’ (Lit. ‘That who will come tomorrow have you told Mary?’)

(73)
[Nor
etorriko d-ela] esan du Mirenek t
uste du-ela Peruk?
who come Aux-that said has Mary think Aux-that Peter
‘Who did Mary say that Peter thinks will come?’ (Lit. ‘That who will come has Mary said (that) Peter thinks?’)

Example (72) is taken to demonstrate the option in Basque for the wh-element (nor) preposed within the embedded clause to pied-pipe the whole embedded CP whose Spec position it came to occupy (the alternative option being to get extracted from it). Notice that the wh-phrase in the embedded CP as well as the whole pied-piped complement CP in the main clause occupy a clause-initial and immediately pre-verbal position characteristic of wh-moved interrogatives in Basque. Example (73) shows that the pied-piped CP can itself be extracted from the embedded Spec, i.e., move successive cyclically, to form a matrix question, in the same way as nonclausal wh-constituents can. Such evidence from Basque leads Ortiz de Urbina to claim that, contrary to Webelhuth's claims, wh-operator features can percolate from Spec of CP to the CP itself, and by this turn the CP into a wh-operator which after undergoing movement to Spec of CP, is able to bind a syntactic variable from there, just like any other wh-phrase would.

Thus, Ortiz de Urbina (1990) proposes a radically different view of the status of CP-pied-piping across languages. Revising Webelhuth's assumption of C being uniformly marked [−wh], he assumes – in the spirit of the wh-criterion – that only a [+wh], i.e., interrogative C, can, and in fact must, have a wh-operator in its Spec. Given the option of operator-feature percolation from Spec to CP (ignoring the convention blocking percolation if the head has the relevant feature too), Ortiz de Urbina claims that a wh-phrase in Spec either percolates its feature to the CP, which would result in CP pied-piping, and will crucially make this wh-phrase lose its operator status, or it fails to percolate its feature to CP, hence it remains an operator itself, and no CP pied-piping will be licensed. From these assumptions he derives the prediction that CPs that are complements to [−wh] (i.e., non-interrogative) selecting heads, as well as non-selected (i.e., adjunct) CPs, may be pied-piped by their wh-Spec, whereas CP complements of [+wh] (i.e., interrogative) selecting heads cannot get pied-piped since they need a wh-operator present in their Spec. This appears to work well for Basque (see (74a) and (74b)), at least as far as the data considered by Ortiz de Urbina are concerned (for some further relevant facts, see Echepare's 1997 alternative analysis referred to below).

(74)
a. [Nor
etorriko d-ela bihar] esan diozu Mireni? Basque
who come Aux-that tomorrow said Aux Mary-Dat
‘Who have you told Mary will come tomorrow?’ (Lit. ‘That who will come tomorrow have you told Mary?’)
b. *[Nor
etorriko d-en] galdetu duzu?
who come Aux-comp asked Aux
(Lit. ‘Who will come have you asked?’)
Cf. the corresponding ungrammatical English *Who have you asked will come?

As for the case of Germanic, such as the examples in (71) from English, Ortiz de Urbina needs to say something additional in order to account for the fact that they are impossible even though the selecting verbs know and forget do permit a [−wh], i.e., a non-interrogative CP complement. The solution he proposes for this problem relies on the difference between Germanic and Basque with respect to whether C is empty or not. Specifically, he suggests that the Germanic cases of CP-pied-piping are ruled out by the ECP (Chomsky 1981, 1986a) due to the lexically ungoverned nature of their empty C in the output structure, i.e., that the unacceptability of examples like (71) has nothing to do with wh-pied-piping per se. While it is clear that some parameter distinguishing Basque and Germanic must be involved, it seems doubtful that it could simply be the emptiness of C in Germanic preposed CPs violating the ECP. If this were so, one would not expect any possibility of a CP in a left-peripheral A-bar or subject position, having a wh-element in its specifier and an empty C. But such cases clearly are attested, as shown by fully acceptable topicalized wh-CPs, such as Who Mary invited, I would never reveal to you, or subject clauses, such as What you got from whom doesn't interest me. A different approach that can provide a reasonable alternative way to derive the apparent cases of CP-pied-piping in Basque, and can also account for the distinct behavior of the English-type languages, is proposed by Echepare (1997) based on some novel data and generalizations he points out regarding Basque interrogatives.

Echepare's major observations leading to the reassessment of the alleged CP-pied-piping phenomenon of Basque are the following: (a) a pied-piped wh-CP cannot satisfy selection for a wh-interrogative, i.e., it can occur only in the Spec of a matrix question but not in an embedded one (see (75)) and (b) the set of wh-words that can pied-pipe a CP is limited to arguments and referential adjuncts, while non-referential wh-adverbials, like ‘why’ and ‘how’, are not able to appear in pied-piped CPs, and can take matrix scope only by extraction (see (76)):

(75)
*Mikelek galdetu du [CP
[nor etorriko dela]i
esan duten ti]. Basque
Mikel ask Aux who come Aux-Comp say Aux-Comp
‘Mikel asked who they said will come.’ (Lit. ‘Mikel asked who will come said they.’)

(76)
*[Zergatik
aspertu zela]i
uste duzu ti?
why bore Aux-Comp think Aux
‘Why do you think she/he got bored?’ (Lit. ‘Why she/he got bored think you?’)

These properties are completely unexpected under a hypothesis of CP-pied-piping by wh-movement (as, e.g., Ortiz de Urbina's 1990 wh-feature-percolation-based proposal above). Echepare (1997) interprets the property demonstrated by (75) (see generalization (i) above) as indication that in fact the preposing of apparent wh-CPs in Basque interrogatives is not due to wh-movement at all, and argues that these CPs are not located in Spec of CP, but rather are topicalized phrases appearing in a projection higher than CP. Furthermore, along the same lines, the impossibility of examples like (76), i.e., ‘pied-piped’ CPs being acceptable only when their wide-scope taking wh-element is an argument or referential adjunct, is taken as indication that the wh-words of Basque are not operators. Echepare argues that they undergo neither overt nor covert wh-movement to Spec of CP; instead, he claims, wh-interrogatives in Basque should be analyzed as in situ wh-questions of the Chinese type, and receive wide-scope construal via unselective binding, since it is this type of wh-construction that is known to exhibit the referentiality restrictions manifested in (76) (see chapter 77). Thus, under Echepare's analysis, Basque would not instantiate wh-movement pied-piping a CP. If apparent CP-pied-piping constructions such as (72) and (73) indeed turn out to involve simply a topicalized CP that in these particular cases just happens to contain an in-situ wh-phrase, then Basque interrogatives would be consistent with Webelhuth's operator-feature-based theory of pied-piping that systematically excludes the possibility of clausal pied-piping.

Finally, there is one slightly different potential instance of CP-pied-piping by Spec within Germanic not addressed in Webelhuth (1992). This is the somewhat controversial case of pied-piped infinitivals occurring in relative constructions of German (see, e.g., Van Riemsdijk 1985 and Grewendorf 1986). Unlike the clausal pied-piping cases of the English stylistically marked, literary kind discussed in section 4.3.1, these sentences in German (such as in (77)), arguably involve overt movement of the relative pronoun within the pied-piped infinitival, as argued by Van Riemsdijk (1985, 1993), namely, movement to the Spec position of the infinitival CP.

(77)
das Buch, [das PRO t
zu lesen] er uns empfohlen hatte
the book which to read he us recommended had
(‘the book, to read which he had recommended to us’)

Apparently, this kind of alleged CP-pied-piping is induced only by the Spec position of the CP, and, consequently, it is a reasonable initial assumption that it involves feature percolation to the CP. Yet it is also possible that this case should be considered nevertheless as a counterpart of the stylistically marked pied-piping cases of English discussed in section 4.3.1; the latter were claimed by Webelhuth (1992) to involve simply topicalization of the constituent, rather than actual pied-piping by movement of a wh-operator. The reason is that it shares two important properties with the latter cases: (a) it is limited to occur only in relative clauses, and is impossible in interrogatives, suggesting that the process actually might not involve quantificational operators, and (b) it is excluded in the case of tensed clauses, which makes it similar to the English clausal-pied-piping cases shown in (61–62) of section 4.3.1. If analyzed in this latter way, one would then need to address the question of what forces the overt preposing of the relative pronoun within the infinitival, and why no such preposing is required (or in fact permitted) within the English cases such as those of Ishihara (1984), shown in section 4.3.1.

On the basis of these observations we can only conclude that no uncontroversial evidence is available in favor of the existence of true CP-pied-piping under wh-movement, in the same sense as there is uncontroversial evidence for DP-pied-piping under wh-movement. Even the strongest candidate discussed in the literature, namely, the case of Basque interrogatives, raises some serious doubts due to evidence internal to the language. Furthermore, it would leave open the issue of the relevant parametric difference between Basque-type languages and languages where interrogatives do not manifest CP-pied-piping.

subsection.heading: 4.6 Pied-piping in non-wh-constructions
subsection.p: So far our discussion has been focusing on wh-constructions and specifically, on accounting for the pied-piping ability of wh-words occupying various structural positions in their phrases. This reflects the orientation of the pied-piping literature itself, at least until recently. The obvious reason for the predominance of studies on pied-piping by wh-morphemes is the overtly detectable nature of this particular morpheme, and the wide range of movement operations it is involved in. Yet an uncontroversial assumption in the literature, shared by all accounts of wh-pied-piping reviewed above, is that the mechanisms proposed for wh-pied-piping generalize (at least) to the whole set of operator features in UG. Some better known cases of such operator features involved in movement, beyond [+wh], are the [+neg] feature of negative morphemes, central to Rizzi's (1991b) Negative Criterion (see also Haegeman and Zanuttini 1991), and within the framework of a systematically checking theory-based account of quantifier scope put forth in Beghelli and Stowell (1997), also quantificational features, such as [+Dist(ributive)], [+Univ(ersal)], and others, corresponding to individual clausal functional heads and QPs. (Another potentially relevant operator feature, namely, the feature [+Focus], proposed in Horvath 1986, and used as a crucial part of Brody's 1990a Focus Criterion, is reexamined and eliminated as such in Horvath 2000, in part based on considerations of pied-piping under overt Focus-movement as manifested in Hungarian.)

These operators are commonly assumed to involve covert (LF) movement, at least in languages like English (however, for an alternative treatment making use only of overt movements, see Kayne 2000: ch. 13). Thus, for instance, QR of the GB framework, as well as its reanalyzed minimalist versions, such as those proposed by Hornstein (1995), Beghelli and Stowell (1997), or the movement of negative phrases to enter into a Spec–Head relation with the clausal head Neg0 to satisfy the Negative Criterion (or to check the [+Neg] feature) are assumed to take place after Spell Out in languages such as English and French (the status of pied-piping under covert movement will be addressed in section 5). Here, however, we will consider pied-piping by such non-wh operators in languages and constructions where these operators undergo uncontroversially overt movements. Such cases are, for example, QR in Hungarian (Kiss 1992), movement of negative phrases to Spec of NegP in Italian and West Flemish (Haegeman and Zanuttini 1991; Haegeman 1995b), and also the Negative Inversion construction in English.

To demonstrate the ability of non-wh operator features to pied-pipe in a way consistent with what we found with respect to wh-movement, first consider examples from Hungarian involving overt Quantifier Raising of the universal quantifier minden ‘every’ to the position of Spec of DistP (postulated in Beghelli and Stowell 1997):

(78)
a. [Mindenkinek ] vettünk valamit t.
everyone-Dat bought-1Pl something-Acc
‘We bought something for everyone.’
b. [Minden
vendégnek] vettünk valamit t.
every guest-Dat bought-1Pl something-Acc
‘We bought something for every guest.’
c. [[Minden
vendég] gyerekének] vettünk valamit t.
every guest's child-Dat bought-1Pl something-Acc
‘We bought something for every guest's child.’

Similarly, the pied-piping generalizations found in relation to wh-movements are attested also in the case of overt movements involving a negative constituent. This can be seen based on the following Negative Inversion examples from English, where, unlike in other instances involving negative phrases in the language, the overt nature of the movement of the [+neg] element (to the Spec of CP) is transparent. (On the question of how to derive their need for aux-inversion, i.e., for I-to-C movement, see Rizzi's 1991b discussion of the Negative Criterion, on a par with his Wh-Criterion.) Consider the pied-piped phrases and the [+neg] morpheme within them in (79), as well as the contrasting pairs (80a)–(80b) and (81a)–(81b); examples (80a, b) show the negative morpheme being able to pied-pipe its DP when occurring in Spec but not when occurring in complement position, and the contrast in (81) shows that when the head of a phrase is [+Neg], it can pied-pipe the whole DP, including a complement, but when the [+Neg] feature is on the complement in a DP, the whole phrase cannot be pied-piped by it.

(79)
a. [Never] have I witnessed such behavior.
b. [Under no conditions] will I leave this city.
c. [[No student's] thesis] have they read so thoroughly.

(80)
a. [[No young girl's] participation in the game] can they permit.
b. *[The participation [of no young girl] in the game] can they permit.

(81)
a. [No articles by such a reporter] will they agree to publish.
b. *[Such articles [by no reporter]] will they agree to publish.

In some of the recent literature, inspired by Kayne's (1994) Antisymmetry framework, pied-piping of large, clausal and other functional projections (both in the nominal and in the verbal extended projections) is postulated on a much larger scale than in earlier work. The empirical evidence for such analyses often comes from surface discrepancies of word order (e.g., the appearance of head-final phrases in head-initial languages) or from various agreement phenomena, which under the restrictive theoretical assumption that agreement holds only in Spec–Head configurations, imply that large phrasal categories – possibly remnants appearing to be no more than just heads – move to Spec positions, as instances of pied-piping by the relevant agreeing feature(s). The existence of such ‘heavy’ pied-piping is discussed from a conceptual point of view by Koopman (1996). In addition to giving a general perspective on a theory with heavy pied-piping, Koopman also reviews some supporting empirical evidence from a variety of languages based on earlier studies (e.g., Nkemnji's 1995 analyses of Nweh (Grassfield Bantu)). To the extent that these large-scale movements are indeed driven by the need for feature-checking and/or agreement (which in these analyses is not always obvious), they would constitute true cases of pied-piping and would raise the obvious question of what induces the apparent language-particular variation with respect to this option, or at least what the properties and mechanisms are that make such heavy pied-piping more easily detectable in some languages than in others.

Most of the earlier literature on pied-piping considered cases of operator movement. Yet there is clearly no reason not to expect pied-piping also when the feature/morpheme-triggering movement is inflectional or categorial in nature rather than an operator; in other words, one may in principle expect pied-piping to occur under A-movements as well. Finding appropriate test-cases for A-movement pied-piping, however, is indeed more difficult, at least in the obvious canonical A-movement cases, such as noun phrase movements to A-positions (e.g., to Spec of IP). One factor limiting the range of testable cases is that having no Case, or in MP terms, having an unchecked Case feature, is a necessary condition for a DP to be eligible for A-movement (see Chomsky 1995c, 2000). However, DPs occurring, for instance, within the Spec position of a larger DP such as some student in [some student's parents] (see (82a)) are already Case-licensed inside the DP; the same is true for complements of N, which bear inherent Case. Thus these DPs cannot undergo A-movement to begin with, hence obviously could not be expected to be potential pied-pipers of their phrase. Another factor that might reduce cases of A-movement pied-piping is that, in contrast to operator movements, the types of features triggering classical A-movements (familiar from Raising or Passive constructions) are precisely those known independently not to be inheritable via the Spec–Head relation, at least when the head is marked for the same features (see section 4.3.2 on pro identification by phi-features inducing an anti-pied-piping effect in free relatives, as well as Webelhuth 1992 on wh-feature percolation). So under a feature-percolation-based view of pied-piping, commonly assumed for operator movements, one would not expect a DP in Spec of DP position to be a pied-piper for its phrase under A-movement.

What we find when turning to the assessment of the actual empirical facts is that pied-piping indeed is attested, in the canonical A-movement cases examined, only when the pied-piper is the head of the phrase, as in (82a) and (82b) below. DPs in Spec of DP position can get pied-piped by the head, but they themselves cannot act as pied-pipers (see (82b)). (Feature inheritance from the head, and hence pied-piping of the maximal projection, is unproblematic, as expected.)

(82)
a. [Some/no student's [parents]] are waiting in the office.
b. *[Some/no student's [parents]] is waiting in the office.

This is contrary to what we find in the case of operator movements such as wh-movement. But as pointed out above, the apparent impossibility of pied-piping by Spec under A-movement in (82b) is in fact independent of the pied-piping mechanism itself, since such DP specifiers cannot undergo A-movement at all as shown in (83) below. (Note that under wh-movement, possessive Spec of DPs in English pied-pipe the rest of the DP obligatorily, putatively for PF-related reasons, discussed in section 6.1).)
(83) *Some/no student(‘s) are [t (‘s) parents] waiting in the office.

The ungrammaticality of (83) cannot be attributed simply to the lack of phi-feature checking (i.e., lack of appropriate agreement) on the clausal head I and of Case on the DP [ . . . parents], since such phi-feature-checking by a Case-bearing DP would be possible without movement, i.e., when the relevant phrase is in post-V rather than in Spec of IP position (see Chomsky 2000 on Agree). This possibility is demonstrated in there expletive constructions, such as (84):
(84) There are some student's parents waiting in the office.

Some versions of the earlier GB theory though would indeed have excluded cases such as (83) above by the lack of Case on the post-V DP in (83), while permitting examples like (84) via expletive replacement.

A distinct contrast of interest involving DP-pied-piping (pointed out by an anonymous referee) is provided by the post-nominal possessive construction of English. The construction exemplified in (85) may represent an instance of DP-pied-piping by its Spec under A-movement (a case we failed to find with pre-nominal possessives as in (82–83)).

(85)
a. [Some students of John's] are waiting in the office.
b. *[Some students] are [t (of) John's] waiting in the office.

Pied-piping here is obligatory – i.e., (of) John's cannot be left stranded by the preposed phrase (85b). Naturally, if the string some students in this construction does not form a constituent, we would not expect it to be able to move independently, and thus strand the rest of the DP. But if Kayne's (1994: 86) analysis of this construction – shown schematically in (86) – is right, then some students is clearly a constituent, one that has been preposed to the Spec of the topmost DP in the structure.
(86) [some studentsi [[D of] [John [‘s [ti]]]]]

Thus, assuming the structure (86) motivated by Kayne, pied-piping of of John's by the phrase some students occupying the Spec position of the highest DP projection is predicted to be possible, and this indeed seems borne out by (85a). Such examples may, under the above analysis, instantiate the case we have been searching for, namely, pied-piping of a DP under A-movement by a phrase in its Spec position. The question remaining under the above analysis is: why is pied-piping obligatory here (see 85b)? The reason for this may have to do with the fact that the preposed phrase in Spec of DP (some students) in this construction is arguably not a DP, but rather a QP/NP (see Kayne 1994). If the EPP driving movement to Spec of IP is in fact a requirement of checking an uninterpretable D feature of the head I (as proposed in Chomsky 1995c), then this would automatically explain why the phrase some students itself could not satisfy the EPP, and hence could not move by itself, only the whole DP could, as shown in (85a, b). (If so, then, technically, the movement would again be DP-pied-piping by its head D, not by its Spec.) However, according to an alternative, more recent, conception the EPP-requirement is not construed as categorial feature-checking, but as the need of the I (=T) head to have a Spec position realized (see Chomsky 2000). Under this approach, there appears to be no obvious reason for the impossibility of (85b), given that the phrase in Spec of DP is a maximal projection (QP or NP) which is demonstrably able to undergo movement by itself in Kayne's account. Possibly, however, this problematic phenomenon could fall together with some observations made in relation to the notion ‘phase’ in Chomsky (2000) involving the impossibility of extracting substantive, i.e., ‘non-phase’, categories from within their functional layer constituting a phase (i.e., from their extended projection). For instance, finite IPs cannot strand their C, and similarly, an NP/QP would not be able to strand its DP layer. (On Spec and obligatory pied-piping, see also section 6.)

A related question of obvious significance is whether A-movement can pied-pipe non-nominal projections, such as VP and various clausal functional projections, by their DP specifier. A case in point would be, for instance, if instead of the subject DP being moved from its VP-internal base position to Spec of IP, as in an English-type SVO language, the same feature-checking and EPP requirement driving the movement of the DP could be satisfied, at least in some languages, by preposing the whole VP/vP or other clausal projection whose Spec position the relevant DP occupies. Notice that being (extended) projections of V, these categories would be less likely to block feature-inheritance from a DP in Spec by their head-projection than nominal projections. (Percolation of non-operator features from the complement would be excluded under (47), just like percolation of operator-features is.) A concrete test case of the above kind from English would be, for instance, the raising construction in (87a, b), where the (bare) IP complement of the raising predicate has a DP in its Spec position. The question is: can this DP pied-pipe the IP, instead of being extracted from it?

(87)
a. *[The students to enjoy the lecture] are likely [t].
b. The students are likely [t to enjoy the lecture].

Pied-piping of IP under A-movement turns out to be clearly impossible in the case of (87). The reason for this again appears to lie in the nature of the category moved (see (87a)). In this case it is a defective IP – i.e., one without a full set of phi-features – in terms of Chomsky (2000). Such IPs, occurring in raising and ECM constructions, are known not to exhibit phonetic autonomy like, e.g., CPs or verb phrases do; specifically, they are unable to move or occur as elliptical answers on their own (e.g., *it's [t to enjoy the lecture] that John seems). While English, at least in the above type of case, does not exhibit the relevant pied-piping option, empirical work on a variety of languages has uncovered putative motivation for assuming pied-piping of VPs and various clausal functional projections by their specifiers under A-movements (see, e.g., Koopman and Szabolcsi 2000 for relevant analyses and references).

subsection.heading: 5 LF-movements and pied-piping
subsection.p: Within the GB model of UG, it was assumed that the same operation Move α involved in mapping D-structures to S-structures also applies to S-structures, and derives from S-structures another level of syntactic representations, namely, LF. These post-S-structure applications of Move α became known as LF-movements, and were also referred to as covert movements, since they had no phonological effects, due to the architecture of the grammar (the T-model). Within such a model, the null hypothesis seems to be that all properties of LF-movement, including in particular the options of pied-piping, will be parallel to those found in the case of overt (i.e., pre-S-structure) movement, apart from any possible properties of overt movement that are imposed by phonological (PF) requirements.

The existence of pied-piping by LF-movements was thus taken for granted in the GB framework. The first actual empirical issue involving pied-piping and LF-movement arose in connection with the assumed LF-movement account of wh-in-situ constructions in languages such as Chinese and Japanese, and also of multiple wh-questions in English-type languages. Specifically, a problem for the expected parallelism between overt and LF-movement operations appeared to exist in relation to the application of Subjacency (Huang 1982a). It was observed that in-situ (non-D-linked) wh-elements, assumed to undergo covert wh-movement, actually permitted certain island violations, and this raised the possibility that LF-movement was not subject to Subjacency. In an attempt to show that LF-wh-movement, too, obeys Subjacency, as one would expect, based on the null hypothesis, an interesting type of proposal was made independently in work by Choe and by Nishigauchi (published as Choe 1987 and Nishigauchi 1990); the analysis was further elaborated by Pesetsky (1987a). The proposal was based on the hypothesis of large-scale pied-piping by the LF-wh-movement involved, and it claimed that the suspected island violations are only apparent, since although the wh-element itself occurs within an island, such as a complex NP or an adjunct, what actually moves at LF is the island itself, in other words, the complex NP or the adjunct gets pied-piped. This movement, unlike extraction of the wh-in-situ element itself, would not violate Subjacency. Both Choe and Nishigauchi provided the type of evidence illustrated in (88), involving the felicity of answers to wh-questions, in support of their claim (example (88) is adapted from Pesetsky 1987a: 113):

(88)
Q: Mary-wa [DP [CP
John-ni nani-o ageta] hito-ni] atta-no? Japanese
Mary-Top John-Dat what-Acc gave man-Dat met-Q
‘What did Mary meet the man who gave to John?’
A1: */?? Konpyuutaa desu.
computer Cop
‘It's a computer.’
A2: [DP [CP
Konpyuutaa-o ageta] hito-ni] desu.
computer-Acc gave man Cop
‘It's the man who gave a computer (to him).’

As shown in (88), only the whole complex NP can be a felicitous answer to the in-situ wh-question. These types of facts are taken to show that the pied-piping of the island by the wh-in-situ element is the only possible derivation in the prima facie problematic cases. Hence, the apparent discrepancy between overt and LF movements with respect to the application of Subjacency would be eliminated. It must be noted here that the above covert pied-piping proposal fails to account for the fact that a certain subset of wh-elements, in particular non-referential adjuncts such as ‘why’ (reason) and ‘how’ (manner), are unable to take wide scope out of islands in such wh-in-situ languages as well (see chapter 77).

Apart from several empirical problems involved in the proposed evidence, such as those pointed out, e.g., in Fiengo et al. (1988), the above account is undesirable from the point of view of the assumptions it makes about LF-pied-piping itself. Crucially, notice that, based on what is known about overt pied-piping, the same wh-in-situ structures that in the above proposal are assumed to undergo LF-pied-piping would obviously not be able to undergo pied-piping by overt wh-movement. Under accounts of overt pied-piping based on variants of a reasonably restrictive and empirically motivated feature percolation or inheritance mechanism (reviewed in section 4), the relevant [+wh] feature would clearly not be able to percolate to the complex NP in cases like (88), and, consequently, pied-piping would be impossible. This problem is best shown by the contrasts in English between overt wh-movement and wh-in-situ (alleged to involve LF-wh-movement) in the case of various islands, such as in (89a, b):

(89)
a. *[The man [who bought what]] did Mary know?
b. Who knew [the man [who bought what]]?

LF-pied-piping by wh-in-situ, then, as formulated in the Choe–Nishigauchi–Pesetsky analysis, seems to resolve the non-uniformity of overt and covert movement with respect to Subjacency only at the cost of introducing another non-uniformity between overt and covert movements, namely, one with respect to the application of pied-piping. This is a serious problem since there is no plausible reason why covert movement should permit ‘heavier’ pied-piping than overt movement. Notice that if any needs of PF (relevant for the output of overt but not covert movement) have any impact on pied-piping options at all, these would presumably go in exactly the opposite direction; they would potentially force pied-piping rather than prevent it, e.g., in case the moved element was too ‘small’ to be pronouncable, such as a feature or a bound morpheme (on such effects of PF, see Chomsky 1995c, discussed in section 6).

Some problems with this LF-pied-piping proposal from the point of view of interpretation were noted by von Stechow (1996) (see also chapter 77). Von Stechow's objections may be resolved under a conception of reconstruction involving the copy theory of movement, combined with appropriate deletion conventions, of the kind suggested in Chomsky (1995c). However, it is important to note at this point that in spite of the inadequacies of this particular account for wh-in-situ and Subjacency, the general idea behind the proposal, namely, LF-pied-piping providing the account for what appear to be various potential island violations, is arguably on the right track. This kind of account, in a slightly amended form, in fact received some striking confirmation in the domain of the LF-movement of negative phrases in French, studied in Moritz and Valois (1994). In this work on French sentence negation, LF-pied-piping was shown not only to exist but to obey the familiar configurational requirements attributed to the restrictive feature-percolation mechanism underlying overt pied-piping.

After establishing that French negative phrases (such as personne) undergo LF-movement to Spec of NegP (not just chain formation with the head of NegP), Moritz and Valois (1994) proceed to explore cases where personne occurs within some larger phrase that can be shown (based on overt wh-movement) to constitute an island for extraction. The pattern of grammaticality they find is that the negative element personne gives well-formed negative sentences in some of these cases, but results in ungrammaticality in another subset of the cases. The mixed pattern suggests first of all that Subjacency is relevant for the LF-movement of negative phrases, and more importantly, that contrary to assumptions of the proposal for wh-in-situ reviewed above, LF-pied-piping cannot apply freely, making all island effects disappear; rather, only certain kinds of configurations can result in LF-pied-piping.

The crucial claim made by Moritz and Valois on the basis of a variety of arguments is that the particular cases where an island can be pied-piped by personne, and thus a Subjacency violation by LF-raising to Spec of NegP can be avoided, are precisely the cases where personne contained in the larger phrase (i.e., in the extraction island) is able to move (covertly) to the highest Spec position of that phrase. Consider, for instance, the contrast between (90) and (91), representing one type of evidence used by Moritz and Valois.

(90)
a. *l’homme donti
Lise a vu [DP
sa (agent) photo ti (theme)]
the-man of-whom Lise has seen his picture
‘the man of whom Lise saw his picture’
b. *Lise n’a vu [DP
sa (agent) photo de personne (theme)].
Lise Neg-has seen his picture of nobody
‘Lise did not see his picture of anybody.’
(Adapted from Moritz and Valois (1994, (49b) and (50b)))

(91)
a. *De quii
Louise est-elle partie [PP
avec [DP
l’amie ti]]?
of whom Louise is-she left with the-friend
‘Whose friend did Louise leave with?’
b. Louise n’est partie [PP
avec [DP
l’amie de personne]].
Louise Neg-is left with the-friend of nobody
‘Louise did not leave with anybody's friend.’
(Adapted from Moritz and Valois (1994, (58a, b)))

The (a) sentences demonstrate the impossibility of extraction from the DP in (90) and the PP in (91). Given this, the crucial evidence regarding LF-pied-piping is provided by the contrast between the negative sentences (90b) and (91b), both of which exhibit personne in a position prohibiting extraction. Apparently, the island effect in (91) can be voided via LF-pied-piping by personne in (91b); since the sentence is well-formed, a [+Neg] phrase must have moved covertly to the Spec of NegP to license the negative head. In contrast, sentence (90b) is ungrammatical, indicating that no movement of a [+Neg] phrase to the Spec of NegP could take place in it. Hence it must be the case that in (90b), not only extraction but crucially, also LF-pied-piping of the whole DP by personne is blocked. This fact about examples like (90b) is related by Moritz and Valois to a constraint widely observed in studies of extraction out of DP in Romance; it limits which argument of an N may move to the Spec of DP, and hence get extracted from DP. Crucially, it has the effect that when a noun phrase has both an agent and a theme, only the agent is able to move to the Spec position of the DP, and possibly get extracted further (this effect is shown overtly by the ungrammatical (90a)). The important point of the above argument is then that the impossibility of LF-piped-piping by personne (a theme) in (90b) and the contrast with the possibility of LF-pied-piping by personne in (91b) would follow if the LF-pied-piping option were dependent on the ability of personne to move to the Spec position of the phrase to be pied-piped (in our cases, the phrase constituting an island for it); in other words, the evidence suggests that personne can pied-pipe the DP by LF-movement only if it comes to occupy the Spec of DP position. Notice that this finding of Moritz and Valois (1994) falls in place immediately in light of the two major conclusions we reached earlier on the basis of overt pied-piping: namely, (a) that pied-piping is possible only as a result of the ‘pied-piped’ phrase acquiring the feature that drives the particular movement (in the above case [+Neg]), and (b) that the feature-percolation mechanism is limited to Spec–Head agreement and to projection from the head of a phrase to the maximal projection (see (47) in section 4.2). Thus, Moritz and Valois's analysis seems to strongly support the assumption that, beyond Move α itself being uniform before and after S-structure/Spell Out, so are the mechanisms that regulate the possibility of pied-piping.

Within some versions of the MP, introducing feature movement to replace the traditional GB conception of Move α, and principles of derivational economy to limit movements strictly to operations necessary to ensure convergence, the very existence of covert phrasal movement was called into question. In particular, Chomsky (1995c) proposed that movement of any material beyond just the formal features themselves is an instance of pied-piping (referred to as “generalized pied-piping”) and furthermore, according to an economy condition postulated, it can take place only when forced by needs of the PF interface, i.e., when the output without it would be ‘unpronounceable’. (On this conception of pied-piping, see also section 6.) Under this strong hypothesis, all covert movements would necessarily be pure feature movements; only overt movements could be phrasal. In the context of this prediction, the evaluation of empirical evidence apparently pointing to the existence of covert phrasal movement, i.e., to the possibility of pied-piping under LF movement, becomes even more important than it was in earlier frameworks.

A particularly important kind of evidence in favor of LF-pied-piping is provided by the phenomenon of antecedent-contained deletion (ACD). The case of ACD constructions, exemplified in (92), is of special interest because the evidence it provides is very different in nature from the more common kind discussed above. In the above types, LF-pied-piping was inferred based on the observed bypassing of particular island effects. However, in the case of ACD, the evidence for LF-pied-piping involves interpretability, namely the resolution of VP anaphora.

(92) John [VP met [DP everyone that I did [VP e]]].
(Interpreted as John met everyone that I met t.)

The essence of the argument from ACD is based on the fact that the elided VP in cases like (92) needs a linguistic antecedent in order to get interpreted, but its antecedent is the matrix VP that the elided VP is contained in. Thus, in the surface representation given in (92) there is no way to assign an interpretation to this null VP, since the process of VP-anaphora interpretation – the copying of the antecedent (the matrix VP) into the null VP – would reintroduce the VP gap itself, resulting in an infinite regress. This problem of regress can be eliminated, however, if there is some independently motivated process removing the elided VP from within the larger VP before the application of the interpretive (copying) procedure of VP-ellipsis. As was originally proposed by May (1985), and elaborated further, for instance, in Larson and May (1990), Fiengo and May (1994), and Fox (1999), precisely such an independently motivated process is QR, applying to the quantified head of the relative clause containing the elided VP. Thus if QR can move not only the quantifier, or the quantificational feature, but can pied-pipe the whole complex noun phrase, including the relative clause with the elided VP in it, to a position outside of the VP that contained it, then ACD inter-pretation would automatically become unproblematic. The LF-representation provided by QR under the assumption that it can involve pied-piping is given in (93).
(93) [DP everyonei that I did [VP e]] [John [VP met ti]]

This covert pied-piping would leave behind a VP of the form [met t] which could now constitute an appropriate antecedent to be copied into the VP gap and provide the proper interpretation for the ACD construction in (92) (on the compatibility of this account with the copy theory of movement in the MP, see Fox 1999):
(94) [DP everyonei that I [VP met ti]] [John [VP met ti]]

Hornstein (1995) proposes a Case-driven, rather than a quantifier-driven, view of the movement involved, but this account, too, relies on the assumption of covert pied-piping – specifically, on pied-piping under covert A-movement. (For proposals using overt movements in the account of ACD, see Baltin 1987 and Kayne 2000: ch. 13.)

subsection.heading: 6 The Minimalist Program and further current directions
subsection.p: As reflected in the discussion of the above sections, the status of pied-piping in the theory has undergone substantial changes since its introduction in the late 1960s until current times, in accord with the evolution of the model of UG in general, and with the shifts in the conception of movement operations in particular.
