Here we will consider briefly the way pied-piping is conceived in current syntactic theorizing and sketch the role it plays and the issues it raises in Chomsky's (1995c, 2000) MP framework and other varieties of contemporary MP-related research.

subsection.heading: 6.1 Feature movement, economy, and generalized pied-piping
subsection.p: From the perspective of the GB framework, the major issue regarding pied-piping was to determine when it has the option to take place and when it is impossible. This in turn was due to the underlying assumption that, just like movement itself, pied-piping has no cost, and that therefore its application does not need to be (though of course may be) forced by some particular structural or other circumstance. In sharp contrast to this, Chomsky's (1995c) MP conception of pied-piping is based on the view of movement operations as involving, ideally, movement of no more than just the formal features of lexical items needed for the checking of corresponding uninterpretable features on some functional head. As pointed out already in section 5, the need for feature checking itself could not drive movement of any extra material beyond the feature itself. In the spirit of the economy of derivation adopted in the MP framework, this is taken to imply that movement of any lexical material, i.e., any pied-piping of material by the attracted or moved feature, referred to by Chomsky as generalized pied-piping, will be possible only to the extent that it is required for the convergence of the derivation at one of the interfaces. Furthermore, given that the most obvious problem with displacing isolated features seemed to be ‘unpronouncability’ – namely the lack of proper interpretation at the PF interface – Chomsky (1995c: 262–263) suggested a stronger version of the above hypothesis, according to which it is only PF needs, such as morphological and phonological properties determining PF convergence, that can induce (generalized) pied-piping. On this conception, pied-piping is viewed as a repair strategy imposed on the computational system by factors external to the system itself.

This PF-based hypothesis works adequately in some cases, as exemplified by the way wh-feature attraction applies to a wh-phrase like whose book (where who is assumed to be in the Spec of DP and ’s is a possessive D, heading the DP). The attracted wh-feature cannot raise by itself since it would result in a crash at PF. So at least the whole lexical item who must be pied-piped; but in the present case, this would leave behind ’s book, a form that would also cause a crash at PF; furthermore, whose (at least in English) cannot raise either, since being made up of the Spec of DP (who) and the head D (’s) it is a non-constituent, i.e., it is not a syntactic object at all, so it cannot be affected by a movement operation. Consequently, the smallest element that can legitimately be raised by Attract/Move [wh] according to Chomsky's (1995c) hypothesis is predicted to be the phrase whose book. It would furthermore be predicted that unless justified by additional PF needs, this would also be the maximal phrase that gets pied-piped; thus, e.g., phrases like read whose book and an article about whose book cannot get pied-piped under wh-feature movement.

Although the PF convergence hypothesis correctly derives pied-piping and, moreover, also the Left Branch Condition effect in the present case, it obviously faces some serious conceptual and empirical challenges. On the conceptual side, the proposed economy condition involving the PF interface means that the determination of how much material is pied-piped each time when Attract applies to some feature in a derivation would involve significant look-ahead, a property known to result in sharply increased computational complexity. However, it is unlikely that such complexity is indeed inherent in overt movements, which manifest no corresponding special difficulty in production and processing (on the elimination of similar computational complexity with respect to Procrastinate and ‘strong’ features, see Chomsky 1995c: 228). One obvious empirical challenge for a purely PF-convergence induced view of pied-piping would be the apparent optionality of some cases of pied-piping, i.e., its alternation with extraction. This is the case, for instance, in wh-phrases in the Spec of DP in Russian-type languages, which permit Left Branch Condition violations, or in the case of Hungarian DPs with dative-marked possessors in the top Spec position (analyzed in Szabolcsi 1983). It is unclear how the larger phrases would be able to get pied-piped in such cases without violating the economy principle of carrying only the minimal amount of material sufficient for PF convergence.

These problems would not arise in the same way under Chomsky's (2000) version of the MP since it gives up the view of overt movement as generalized pied-piping, treating it as a ‘repair strategy’ for (pre-Spell Out) feature movement. It reanalyzes feature movement as long-distance agreement via the operation Agree and separates the case of overt movements from this feature-checking process in a way that makes overt movement essentially independent of the need of eliminating uninterpretable features. Instead, all overt movements are viewed as satisfying a further requirement imposed by particular functional heads to have a specifier projected (similarly to early versions of the EPP). Under this view the movement of overt material, namely, of a phrase, would no longer be a case of pied-piping induced by PF convergence. However, the empirical problem of how ‘big’ the moved phrase can be, i.e., what constituent can be legitimately moved to satisfy these ‘EPP’ requirements, is still a major issue.

It might be possible to deal with the problems of PF-convergence-induced pied-piping while maintaining the assumptions of feature movement and the economy principle of ‘carry as little as possible’ in some form. This involves trying to attribute the existence of phrasal movements not exclusively to the needs of PF convergence, but at least in part to the interaction of the above economy principle, requiring movement of the minimal element, with a major independently motivated economy principle of Chomsky (1995c: 297) built into the Attract operation. The latter condition requires Attract to target the closest feature that can enter into a checking relation with a feature of the attracting head (exemplified, e.g., in Superiority effects). Given that a feature (say, [wh]) occurring, for instance, on a morpheme in the Spec of a Spec of DP, such as in [whose friend's mother], would be further away (under an appropriate definition of ‘closeness’) from the wh-attracting C-head of the clause than the whole large DP itself, the condition ‘closest’ on Attract would force it to target the large DP, rather than the wh-morpheme who. This assumes that the wh-feature was present not only within the Spec of the Spec of the DP, but – due to feature percolation (motivated earlier) – also on the large DP itself. Such a proposal would have the further advantage of being able to maintain the desirable empirical results of the earlier feature-percolation based accounts of pied-piping with respect to the possible phrase-internal positions of pied-pipers, as discussed in section 4. In a framework permitting feature-movement, this proposal would of course still need to avoid movement of just the bare wh-feature that percolated to the large DP in the case under discussion, and induce raising of that whole DP instead. But this would follow as before; bare feature movement prior to Spell Out would be excluded by the assumption that features displaced from their lexical item cause a PF-crash (Chomsky 1995c). This type of conception of phrasal movement is explored in Pesetsky (2000), where the option of phrasal vs. feature or morpheme movement is seen as moving the closest bearer vs. the smallest bearer of the relevant feature, both being considered ways of satisfying derivational economy.

subsection.heading: 6.2 Phrasal movement vs. head movement, large-scale pied-piping, and the elimination of feature movement
subsection.p: The empirical issue of correctly accounting for how big a constituent bearing the relevant feature ends up moving can be – in other words, what constituent gets pied-piped by the minimal element needed for feature-checking – arises independently of whether the theory postulates feature movement per se and whether one assumes an economy-based preference for moving the smallest element possible (as Chomsky's 1995c version of the MP did). Notice, for instance, that given the well-motivated feature-percolation mechanism underlying pied-piping, the problem of determining the choice between moving a head and moving the whole phrase (both bearing the same features) may arise in any framework in which movement is driven by feature-checking, even in one stipulating that features cannot move, i.e., that movements apply only to categories (as under Move α of the GB framework).

Notice that in GB theory this problem did not seem to arise. In that framework, movements were stipulated to involve requirements of individual Spec positions vs. requirements of particular heads, e.g., in the case of the Wh-Criterion, or the affix triggering V-to-I. This property, in conjunction with the structure preservation hypothesis (Emonds 1976; Chomsky 1986a), fully determined which movement will be phrasal movement and which will be head movement. Under the MP checking theory, however, this is no longer true, since the feature in need of checking (attracting to itself an element with a matching feature) always occurs on a functional head; specifiers as such are designated to play a role only in the more recent, EPP-based version of overt movement suggested in Chomsky (2000) (see section 6.1).

Empirically, the issue of head vs. phrasal movement calls for further investigation. Yet, based on the range of cases studied, it appears that feature-checking, if it induces overt movement at all, induces pied-piping of a phrase rather than just the head (for evidence see, e.g., Koopman and Szabolcsi's 2000 study of verb-raising structures). This may in turn follow automatically if head movement is in fact not an option in the computational system at all, only at PF (a hypothesis suggested recently on the basis of a variety of independent considerations for instance by Chomsky 2000, Boeckx and Stjepanović 2001 and others). If so, head movement could provide no alternative to feature-checking via phrasal movement.

Yet, a similar issue of whether or not a larger constituent XP gets pied-piped in the case of a phrase YP occurring in the Spec of XP remains an empirical problem, as it was for the previous hypotheses. The Spec position has been seen to be a position potentially permitting pied-piping of the phrase (given the Spec–Head agreement based feature percolation or inheritance mechanism). The question of when this option is taken and when the element in Spec extracts rather than pied-pipes the larger phrase would seem a priori to be subject to variation both within and across languages. In fact it is precisely this choice between extraction from Spec and pied-piping of the whole phrase by Spec provided by UG that is claimed in Koopman and Szabolcsi (2000) to provide the basis for cross-linguistic as well as language-internal variation observed in the cases they studied.

An alternative, more challenging, hypothesis regarding pied-piping options is proposed in work by Koopman (1996, 1997). In exact opposition to Chomsky's (1995c) economy principle minimizing the amount of pied-piped material, the hypothesis developed in this direction of research, conceptually inspired by Kayne's Antisymmetry framework, is that massive large-scale pied-piping is in fact the core operation by which derivation proceeds. This line of research makes use of no economy principles and stipulates no feature movement; instead it argues that large-scale pied-piping of different projections by feature-driven ‘licensing’ movements within the functional layers of lexical categories is common, and, possibly, is the only option permitted by UG. Although these may be harder to detect than ‘smaller’, e.g. DP or PP, pied-piping, they can be argued for on empirical grounds, such as various agreement phenomena (for references, see Koopman 1996). The reason given for why the alleged cases of large-scale heavy pied-piping escaped notice is that in structures with multi-layered functional projections above each lexical head (forming an extended projection in Grimshaw's 1991 terminology) the movement of large constituents (e.g., various clausal projections) to nearby Spec positions is hard to overtly detect, especially when the head of the phrase it lands in is null. In fact, Koopman (1997) suggests that contrary to standard assumptions (see above), extraction from Spec is prohibited, and what appears to be extraction from Spec is actually pied-piping of the whole phrase that happens to be a remnant, containing overt material only corresponding to its Spec. Thus, the multiplicity of a universal set of functional categories generated above each lexical head assumed in current versions of the MP, in conjunction with the extensive use of remnant movement assumed in the above line of research, give a rather different picture of the pied-piping issue than previous theories did. Instead of a limited, relatively insignificant, property of movements, pied-piping in such a framework of assumptions is a major syntactic device that is a concomitant, essentially, of all movement. What forces such large-scale pied-piping is less clear; it obviously is not an economy condition that serves to maximize pied-piping. It appears that extensive heavy pied-piping is induced in the above version of the theory by directly eliminating potential alternatives from UG, for instance, by stipulating that bare feature-movements and extraction from Spec position do not exist.

In view of the emerging diverse hypotheses and research sketched above, what seems clear at this point is that pied-piping will be an important focus of attention and empirical investigation in the coming years of work in syntactic theory.
